A network of 150 small producers and farmers who belong to the Campo Aperto association provide the fresh produce, while the collective is managed by 400 ‘partners’ all between 20 and 80 years old (students, professionals, and pensioners) who have a stake in the business. It’s no small feat to go up against large supermarket chains, likely why the national coop launches in Bologna, the capital and largest city of the Emilia-Romagna Region in Northern Italy.“The partners, in addition to paying €125 per person for a membership fee, participate directly in the management of the supermarket by providing three hours a month of their time to work. Only they can buy the products,” explains Giovanni Notarangelo, 42, an engineer and vice president of the cooperative. They alternate between working as cashiers, cleaning, restocking shelves, and all other concerns that make up the day to day business operations of a supermarket (from accounting to building relationships with suppliers). “This project was born from a union between the Cooperative Purchasing Groups of Bologna (Gruppo d’Acquisto Solidale di Bologna) and the association of small peasant farmers from Campo Aperto,” adds Notarangelo. “The goal is to create a direct and transparent supply chain between production and sales, respecting the working conditions of those who produce and the quality of products sold. This way we can break the mechanism of large retailers that impose production standards, quantities and low prices to producers.”
On the shelves of the Camilla coop, you’ll find bread, rice, pasta, vegetables and fresh fruit,cheese, coffee and tomato preserves—soon there will also be detergents and cosmetics— that all meet specific requirements: “These are mainly organic products produced by the farmers of Campi Aperti, or from small business driven by some kind of social good,” explains Notarangelo. He gives an example of what a typical shopping trip looks like: “A panettone produced by the social coop Libero Mondo, two kilos of rice, pureed tomato by the association Sfrutta Zero (Zero Wasta), a glass jar of tuna, beer from an artisanal microbrewery, coffee from the association Tatawelo that supports local farmers in Mexico and Guatemala, and then lentils, chickpeas and beans. All this, from Camilla, cost me 37 euros.” The pasta is sold at 1.20 per kilo, and 3 euros for rice. But beyond the comparison with traditional supermarkets, where prices are lower, the coop’s objective remains political: [We want] “to demonstrate that a different way of making purchases is possible, to forge harmonious ties between producers and consumers.” Giorgia Liberati, 28, also an engineer, underscores this sentiment: “This is a place where you are informed about the entire supply chain, and the self-management model adds value to this alternative experience compared to large retailers. Our size also allows us to address a wider target than that of many small [organic] markets.”
The idea of an self-sufficient supermarket is appealing, as evidenced by the number of partners and the speed—three years—with which the project has come to fruition: “It’s a question of justice,” says Giordana Alberti, 70, who is retired and a founding partner. “Very often the producers are underpaid while sales generate exploitation, but here we need to give life to a new humanism. This is a group that wants to wake people up, we want to give the possibility to develop an economy at ‘zero kilometers’ in the neighboring area.”

title: Different mortality rate among Italian soldiers in WWI: 90,000 less victims
content:
In all the history books, the Italian army’s losses during the WWI is estimated at 650,000. They came to this conclusion immediately after the war, and it’s been hardly questioned since. But that may all change.In recent years, the number of deceased during WWI has been subject to revision in various European countries. This is due, on the one hand, to the possibility of using new IT tools to manage and process large amounts of data. On the other hand, a larger of pool of experts is eager to study similar phenomena: What was once the exclusive work of military historians, is now also a concern for demographers with a vested interest in revisiting the facts.
Alessio Fornasin, Research Associate in Demography at the University of Udine and at the University of Trieste, has been uncovering new sources for some years, with interesting results. As mentioned, the data so far universally accepted was that the Italian victims amounted to 650,000, including 100,000 who died in captivity. This exceptional high mortality rate of our inmates was estimated by the Special Commission of Inquiry appointed immediately after the conflict, but it has long been forgotten by historians and the country’s civil conscience (largely due to the fact that during the war, the Italian authorities refused to rescue their soldiers who were held captive in foreign prison camps as the other warring nations did). Comparing this data collected in 1926 by Corrado Gini (Istat’s future president) with investigations carried out on those who were actually enrolled, Fornasin instead reached a figure of 50,000 Italian deaths in captivity. Either way, a mortality rate higher than that of France, the United Kingdom, and Germany.Even more interesting are the results related to the total number of deaths. Until now, the accepted figure was that proposed by the Commission for War Reparations and submitted by Italy to Germany (who were blamed for the attack that led to the beginning of the war). Fornasin compared the official figures with the official compendium of “Fallen Soldiers”–a gigantic work of 28 volumes, published between 1926 and 1964–which shows the names of all those who died during the war or went “missing” (excluding deserters and people who were shot for example).
This source reports a total of 529,000 dead or missing until December 31, 1920, including those who died from injuries, imprisonment or diseases (such as the devastating outbreak of Spanish flu) while in combat. To this figure, Fornasin proposes to add an estimate of 30,000 deaths derived from in-depth analysis of a new sample size, including those who were excluded or omitted from the Register.This would bring down total the number of deceased Italians during WWI to 560,000; or 90,000 less than initially estimated at Versailles. As many as 35 percent of these died of illness, although it is not possible to know if they would not have died from the same cause.What’s more, the highest number of deaths occurred–due to illness or imprisonment–in 1918 and not, as originally thought, in 1917, or the year of Caporetto. This proves that as accurate as historical accounts may seem, they often still need to be revisited.

title: Three more members of the Higher Health Institute (ISS) quit
content: The rift between the scientific community and the Five Star Movement is growing. Yesterday, a dispute between Italy’s health minister, Giulia Grillo–from the vaccine-skeptic MS5 party–and scientists of the Higher Health Institute (Istituto Superiore di Sanità) led to the resignation of three of the institute’s leading scientists: Giuseppe Remuzzi, Armando Santoro, and Francesco Vitale. Their resignations follows that of ISS president Walter Ricciardi, who quit on Wednesday. Board member Giuseppe Remuzzi and scientific committee member Armando Santoro’s reason for resignations cited lack of independence in the research body. The clash between the institutions puts the right-wing party MS5 in a tight spot, who until recently has held strategic positions in the most important health and scientific institutions. Earlier this month, Italy’s health minister fired all 30 independent members of the country’s Superior Health Board in an abrupt move that was heavily criticized. Among those fired at the time was former council president, Roberta Siliquini, who also serves as the head of the school of hygiene and preventive medicine at the University of Turin. But nothing compares to the latest resignation of the ISS’ top leading scientists, who sceptics may argue were pressured into the decision. “Whoever put these rumors out there, with clear political intent, must take responsibility for their statements, as they are very serious and detrimental to the honor of the institutions and their representatives,” said the health minister. “Whoever is circulating these vile accusations will answer in the appropriate places.” In addition, the health minister said that there has never been any interference with the ISS researchers, staff or managers to pressure their work, and that as minister she has never acted in any way to control them. Deputies of the Social Affairs Commission came to the defense of Grillo, denouncing “political rationale” behind the timing of the resignations, which is being used as a way to discredit Ministry of Health and therefore the government.Despite critics backing down from their attack of the independence of the Institute, the tone of the controversy remains high. Remuzzi recalls that having written his letter of resignation as early as July, but remained on board by way of Ricciardi until the budget was approved. His advice to the government: “We need to look for skills that are fundamental and not ad hoc, and politicians have and will always need scientists.” A not-so subtle reference to Grillo’s idea of “appointing people from bottom-up”.“I’m leaving because I strongly believed in the project Ricciardi put in place in case a decision like this had to be made,” Vitale, head of the scientific committee of the ISS and Head of the University of Palermo said. This solidarity with Ricciardi is echoed by Santoro, director of the Humanitas cancer center, who is distancing himself from the positions taken by the government and the Ministry “on the subject of vaccines”, and in “the manner in which the Higher Health Council was dissolved.”By the evening the ISS directors took pen to paper to assure that the institution “has been and remains independent”–a sign that the scientific world may not be as rebellious against its gatekeepers after all.

title: Revolt in Ciociaria against new populist academy
content: The Trisulti monastery in Collepardo, nestled in the woods and surrounded by the Ciociaria mountains, will not be filled with students who want to master the tools of populist politics just yet. The academy, which is set to be a think-tank to train future politicians, is facing increasing backlash by locals, and on Saturday, citizens of the municipality will march towards the Charterhouse to protest the project which would indelibly transform this place of peace, hospitality, and passage into an academy of international populism.Looking to understand what is about to happen “inside the stone walls of the Trisulti monastery, [where] for more than eight centuries, monks have lived in quiet seclusion, praying, reading and concocting medicinal remedies with herbs from the surrounding forest,” even The Washington Post has come to report. And locals aren’t too happy about this newfound interest either. “Now we’ll be a country of fascists,” says Aldo, an old man who shakes his head with great disappointment. “I’ve always been a Christian Democrat, I’m not a left-winger but I do not like this situation”. Aldo refuses to provide his full name: “These are not times of sincerity,” he apologizes.Mayor Mauro Bussiglieri admits that almost everybody is against the project. “Citizens are having a hard time understanding that the [monastery] is going to be a place where future politicians are going to be trained. They keep looking at it as a religious place, and that’s it.” Others have taken issue with the project saying it defends the “Judeo-Christian values” of Western civilization.On Saturday, citizens who oppose fascism will march in protest against the project, which is set to open in 2020. The think-tank is spearheaded by Benjamin Harnwell, a 44-year-old Englishman, and close associate of former Breitbart executive, Steve Bannon. Bannon has called Harnwell a “pioneer” and a “great genius.” And this “pioneer”, has no problem describing how Bannon’s ambitions will come to fruition thanks to donations by American and British philanthropists who want their children to grow up in a country similar to the one in which they grew up. The Washington Post poses the fateful question: “Can a place where monks once upheld vows of silence now produce the next generation of European populist leaders like Matteo Salvini of Italy and Viktor Orban of Hungary?”Harnwell, busy recruiting teachers, is now living in the monastery with the last 83-year-old monk, some feral cats and a longtime chef-gardener. Since the agreement between the Human Dignity Institute and the Ministry of Cultural Heritage has been signed, the monastery has been less accessible, and only through guided tours. And this is another reason the people of Collepardo are enraged the Charterhouse has been awarded to the alt-right, says Daniela Bianchi, former regional councilor. One would be hard-pressed to blame Salvini’s government as the winning bid was approved by leftist Minister of Culture, Dario Franceschini. “It’s true,” Bianchi says, but adds that at the time (2017), Harnwell hadn’t revealed his true intentions until the Charterhouse had been acquired. “There was a very quiet visit from Bannon before his declaration of turning the Charterhouse into a political school. We are talking about a common good endorsed by the Ministry and in a monastic fortress that symbolizes dialogue and union, not conservative closure. The announcement put forward very specific tasks, which will need to be verified to see if they’re being respected.” “Saturday will not just be a march on Trisulti against Bannon, but also a moment to put forward alternative proposals so that this foreign voice in our community does not remain unchallenged,” Bianchi adds.

title: Museum attendance booms in Italy; a victory for its most courageous directors
content:
Italy may not have a museum the size of the Louvre–which reportedly broke its attendance record in 2018 with over 10 million visitors–but our many small, large, and unmissable cultural institutions have marked a significant increase in admissions tickets sold this past year. This growth is often–as in the case of the Uffizi Gallery, which leads in the national ranking with 4 million admissions, followed by Palazzo Pitti (up by 25 percent) and the Boboli Gardens– due to the courage displayed by directors who experiment with new algorithms. For one, Eike Schmidt was able to eliminate long queues at the Uffizi Gallery (bringing down wait time by one million less waiting hours in a year) and James Bradburne, who heads the Pinacoteca di Brera, expects another 6 percent growth in admissions, exceeding his already brilliant performance of 2017. Even if the data doesn’t officially come out until after the end of December, 386.415 visitors already were already recorded. The gallery is constantly growing and continues to sell more admissions tickets–in November there were 351,531 visitors; about 35,000 new visitors in just that month. Increased interested in the last three months is largely due to the completion of the museum’s three-year long renovations–housing many important masterpieces in its 38 rooms–and the opening of Caffè Fernanda.
The National Archaeological Museum (Mann) of Naples experienced the most significant surge in visitors. Directed by Paolo Giulierini for a third year, the museum tripled its amount of visitors from 520,000 to 615,000 since the beginning of his tenure. “Thanks to a continuous restructuring of the museum we have grown by 20 percent and the goal is now to reach one million visitors,” said the director. Another excellent performance came from Royal Museums of Turin, led by Enrica Pagella. Admissions grew by 27 percent from 461,250 admissions to 515.632 thanks to exhibitions appreciated by foreigners, like the ongoing one dedicated to the masterpieces of the Flemish court painter, Van Dyck. Elsewhere in Turin, the Egyptian Museum ended 2018 with 850,000 visitors, in line with the previous year. But, as President Evelina Christillin points out, we should not forget the many exhibitions the museum sets up around the world (currently in China, Canada, and the United States) which have attracted for 4,1 million visitors in total and allowed people to admire Turin’s Egyptian collections from the other side of the planet. In Rome, the Vatican Museums deserve special mention, with 6,5 million visitors (up by 300,000 visitors this year compared to the record reached in 2017 with 6,2 million visitors)–but that “due to the halls’ limited capacity, the figure will be hard to surpass,” explain the museums’ directors. Suffice it to say that on Christmas Eve, if you wanted to reach the Sistine Chapel, you’d be elbowing people for an hour in a bus-like climate during rush hour. Meanwhile, the Colosseum remains the most visited tourist destination in Italy with 7.6 million visitors. 
Contemporary art also enjoys a growing audience. The Castello di Rivoli Museum in Turin, for example, marked a 7 percent increase in attendance under the dedication of its director, Carolyn Christov Bakargiev, while the Maxxi of Rome (National Museum of 21st Century Arts), recorded a total of 200,000 visitors just in the days before talks began regarding drastic budget cuts. They put on nine admirable exhibitions, many of which were co-produced with the permanent collection, and during the Christmas period it saw up to 1,000 admissions a day, or a 10 percent increase in ticket sales and a 16 percent increase in proceeds. Venice’s museums didn’t go out with a bang last year, but rather maintained high admissions rates as of 2017. The Palazzo Ducale saw 1,35 million visitors (notably, the Tintoretto exhibition attracted 126,000 visitors in three months), while the Gallerie dell’Accademia witnessed an ever so slight decline (although the data is unofficial) of 300,000 admissions compared to 317,000 in 2017. A final museum that is thriving despite having little to do with classical culture is the J Museum, dedicated to the football team Juventus. At 180,000 visitors, this audience greatly prefers the Golden Ball won by Nedved compared to Michelangelo’s Tondo Doni.

title: Parigi-Roma, un anno ad alta tensione diplomatica
content: Ancora alta tensione diplomatica sull’asse Roma-Parigi. L’ambasciatrice d’Italia nella capitale francese, Teresa Castaldo, è stata convocata al ministero degli Esteri francese dopo le parole del vice premier Luigi Di Maio sulla ’moneta coloniale’.Ieri, in particolare, il vicepremier durante una manifestazione del M5S in Abruzzo ha affermato che “la Francia continua ad avere delle colonie di fatto, con il franco”. Parigi, secondo il ministro, usa tali risorse “per finanziare il suo debito pubblico” e parallelamente “indebolisce le economie di quei paesi da dove, poi, partono i migranti”.Le tensioni delle ultime ore costituiscono il nuovo capitolo di un rapporto che, dallo scorso anno, è stato condizionato da un confronto spesso aspro sul tema dell’immigrazione. A marzo è esploso il primo caso Bardonecchia, legato agli sconfinamenti contestati agli agenti francesi che si sono ripetuti anche in autunno. “A seguito di quanto accaduto a Bardonecchia nella serata di venerdì 30 marzo, il ministero degli Affari Esteri e della Cooperazione Internazionale ha immediatamente chiesto spiegazioni alle autorità francesi, sia tramite l’Ambasciata di Francia a Roma, sia tramite la nostra Ambasciata a Parigi”, spiegava un anno fa la Farnesina.“Non avendo ricevuto alcuna giustificazione per il grave atto (considerato del tutto al di fuori della cornice della collaborazione tra Stati frontalieri), si è deciso di convocare oggi pomeriggio, alla Farnesina, l’ambasciatore di Francia in Italia, Christian Masset”, aggiungeva il ministero degli Esteri.All’epoca, “il Direttore Generale per l’Unione Europea, Giuseppe Buccino Grimaldi, ha rappresentato all’ambasciatore la ferma protesta del Governo italiano per la condotta degli agenti doganali francesi, ritenuta inaccettabile e ha manifestato, al contempo, disappunto per l’assenza di risposte alle nostre richieste di spiegazioni”. A giugno, invece, i toni si sono alzati in relazione alla vicenda che ha coinvolto la Aquarius. La nave, dopo la chiusura dei porti italiani, ha attraccato a Valencia. La posizione del governo italiano è stata criticata in Francia ai più alti livelli.Il 13 giugno, quindi, il ministro degli Esteri, Enzo Moavero Milanesi, ha convocato alla Farnesina l’ambasciatore francese Christian Masset e, data la sua assenza da Roma, ha ricevuto l’Incaricata d’Affari, Claire Anne Raulin. Moavero, come ha spiegato la Farnesina, nella circostanza “ha comunicato che il governo italiano considera inaccettabili le parole usate nelle dichiarazioni pubbliche rese” il 12 giugno “a Parigi, anche a livello governativo, sulla vicenda della nave Aquarius. Il ministro Moavero ha chiarito che simili dichiarazioni stanno compromettendo le relazioni tra Italia e Francia”.Nella nota, venivano stigmatizzati i toni “ingiustificabili, tenuto conto che da molti mesi ormai il nostro Paese ha pubblicamente denunciato l’insostenibilità dell’attuale situazione di latitanza di un approccio coordinato e coeso a livello europeo circa la gestione dei flussi migratori, rispetto ai quali l’Italia non si è mai tirata indietro”.

title: Inflazione al 10 milioni per cento, cibo e farmaci introvabili: alle radici della crisi del Venezuela
content:
Aumenti del salario minimo a raffica (otto nel 2018, 26 negli ultimi otto anni), creazione di una criptomoneta ancorata al petrolio, annunci roboanti su un futuro roseo. Tutte le mosse di Maduro, anche le più fantasiose, si sono rivelate inutili per rianimare un Paese allo stremo. Nel discorso di fine anno, dal 2016, va ripetendo che «questo sarà l’anno della ripresa economica». Una menzogna che farebbe sorridere se non fosse che la gente, in Venezuela, muore di fame. 
La verità è che il bolivar, la valuta locale, non vale più nulla. Carta straccia. L’inflazione ha ormai raggiunto sette zeri: ciò che prima costava un dollaro, ora ne costa 100 mila. La previsione del Fondo monetario internazionale parla di 10 milioni per cento per il 2019. Cifre mai raggiunte prima. E la situazione non fa che peggiorare. Quando il fondo sembra raggiunto, il baratro diventa ancora più profondo. Nel Paese con le più grandi riserve petrolifere al mondo - negli anni ’70 era soprannominata Venezuela Saudita - si fa fatica a trovare alimenti e beni di prima necessità. Le code per comprare pane, olio e uova sono chilometriche. Alcune persone hanno abbandonato il lavoro per dedicarsi a sopravvivere. Letteralmente: stanno in fila tutto il giorno per procurarsi il cibo. Alcune medicine, poi, sono quasi introvabili, se non al mercato nero a cifre astronomiche. Per questo la gente continua a scappare. L’Onu stima che i venezuelani che hanno lasciato il Paese raggiungeranno, nel corso del 2019, l’impressionante cifra di cinque milioni (un sesto della popolazione). 
L’isolamento politico del Venezuela non è mai stato così forte. L’insediamento di Maduro, al secondo mandato, è stato boicottato da quasi tutti i leader regionali: c’erano gli storici alleati (il boliviano Evo Morales, il cubano Miguel Díaz-Canel e il nicaraguense Daniel Ortega) insieme a rappresentanti russi e cinesi, creditori milionari del regime, e improbabili emissari delle autoproclamate repubbliche di Ossezia del Sud e Abkhazia. Finché Mosca e Pechino sosterranno Maduro, le sanzioni statunitensi non scalfiranno il regime.

title: Sondaggio Eurobarometro sull’antisemitismo: “Ancora tanto, troppo, presente”
content:
Vandalismo, frasi sgradevoli e offensive, commenti poco lusinghieri. E poi ancora, la negazione dell’Olocausto. L’Europaha ancora molto da fare, ha ancora molto da farsi perdonare. Gli Stati membri dell’Ue sembrano avere seri problemi a fare i conti con il proprio passato, quello buio, perché a distanza di 74 anni dalla fine della Shoah l’antisemitismo è ancora tanto, troppo presente. Ovunque è percepito e riconosciuto come un problema, e quasi nessuno è dell’idea che il fenomeno si sia attenuato.I dati che emergono dallo speciale sondaggio Eurobarometro dedicato esclusivamente all’antisemitismo offrono una panoramica tutt’altro che rassicurante. La metà esatta degli europei (50%) ritiene che l’antisemitismo sia un problema nel loro paese, e solo un cittadino dell’Ue su dieci (10%) è convinto che questo problema si sia «sgonfiato» nell’ultimo lustro. La maggioranza relativa degli europei (39%) è dell’idea che la situazione non sia cambiata, che sia rimasta grosso modo uguale a cinque anni fa. Non un bel segnale. «Combattere l’antisemitismo deve rimanere in cima all’agenda politica», riconosce il commissario europeo per la Giustizia, Vera Jourova.
Gli europei sono divisi sul tema. Il problema di fondo è questo, e viene confermato quando si chiede agli intervistati di tutta l’Ue se «le persone che negano il genocidio del popolo ebraico, l’Olocausto, sono un problema» nel loro Paese. Dice «sì» il 53% dei rispondenti. Il 38% dice «no», il 9% non sa che dire. E’ la situazione che lascia senza parole. Jourova avverte: «Dobbiamo essere vigili e ricordare le parole di Primo Levi, il famoso autore e sopravvissuto all’Olocausto: “Quelli che negano Auschwitz sarebbero pronti a rifarlo”».
La situazione non cambia se si provano a fare altre domande. E’ un problema l’antisemitismo su internet? A rispondere in modo affermativo è il 51% degli intervistati. E scritte sui muri contro ebrei o atti vandalici contro edifici del mondo culturale e confessionale ebraico? Anche qui a definirlo un problema è il 51% degli intervistati. Ancora: atti vandalici nei cimiteri ebraici o aggressioni fisiche? Lo definisce un problema il 50% degli intervistati, in entrambi dei casi. C’è un problema, e Jourova non lo nasconde. Ricorda che a dicembre i leader dei Ventotto hanno sottoscritto una dichiarazione per lottare contro il fenomeno. E’ stato istituito un gruppo di lavoro di alto livello, e adesso «è urgente intensificare la nostra azione contro l’antisemitismo all’interno di questo gruppo, alla luce dei recenti dati disponibili a livello dell’Ue».
All’ignoranza storica e culturale si aggiunge anche quella normativa. C’è un buona fetta di europei che non sa che l’ordinamento giuridico del Paese in cui vivono contiene dispositivi anti-odio. Più di sei europei su dieci (61%) sanno che esiste una legge nel loro paese che criminalizza l’incitamento alla violenza o l’odio nei confronti degli ebrei. Vuol dire che ce ne sono quattro che invece non lo sanno.
Le persone interpellate in Italia offrono l’immagine di un Paese un po’ diverso dal resto d’Europa, ma non così tanto. C’è maggiore consapevolezza sull’antisemitismo come problema (58%, contro la media Ue del 50%), ma c’è anche l’impressione della difficoltà del problema: sette persone su dieci (69%) ritengono che la situazione non sia migliorata negli ultimi cinque anni. A ritenere il negazionismo motivo di preoccupazione sei intervistati su dieci (61%, contro il 51% dell’Ue), al pari di dichiarazioni ostili nei luoghi pubblici (61%), atti di vandalismo (60%) e aggressioni (60%).

title: Esplode un oleodotto in Messico, almeno 66 morti e 76 feriti
content: Il bilancio dell’esplosione di un oleodotto nello Stato messicano di Hidalgo è salito a 66 morti e 76 feriti. Lo ha confermato il governatore, Omar Fayad, precisando che si tratta di una cifra non definitiva.Lo scoppio ed il successivo incendio hanno interessato nel pomeriggio di ieri un tratto dell’oleodotto Tuxpan-Tula nel municipio di Tlahuelilpan, ad un centinaio di chilometri da Città del Messico.In una conferenza stampa insieme al presidente messicano Andre’s Manuel Lopez Obrador, il governatore di Hidalgo, Fayad, ha confermato l’aggravamento del bilancio.Il responsabile ha spiegato che prima dell’esplosione le forze federali avevano ripetutamente, ma inutilmente, chiesto alla popolazione, intenta a raccogliere il combustibile fuoriuscito dall’elodotto, di allontanarsi per i pericoli esistenti.

title: Lasciano acqua a migranti nel deserto, quattro donne a processo negli Stati Uniti
content: Quattro donne sono state giudicate colpevoli da un giudice federale dell’Arizona per aver lasciato cibo e acqua nel deserto per salvare migranti irregolari.Il giudice federale Bernardo Velasco ha emesso il suo verdetto contro Natalie Hoffman, Oona Holcomb, Madeline Huse e Zaachila Orozco, volontarie dell’associazione «No more deaths» (Basta morti), per essere entrate senza permesso e aver portato bottiglie d’acqua nel rifugio Cabeza Prieta vicino a Ajo, in Arizona, dove nel 2014 morirono 91 migranti irregolari. Una di loro deve rispondere anche dell’accusa di essere entrata nella riserva con l’auto. Le imputate rischiano ora una condanna fino a sei mesi di carcere a una multa di 500 dollari.L’associazione «No more deaths» giudica il verdetto «un affronto non solo per l’associazione ma per tutte le persone di coscienza del Paese». «Se dare acqua a qualcuno che rischia di morire di sete è illegale, quale umanità resta nella legge di questo Paese?», fa notare Catherine Gaffney, volontaria del gruppo.Nel suo verdetto, il giudice Velasco ha indicato che i litri d’acqua lasciati dai volontari all’interno dell’area protetta «erodono la decisione nazionale di mantenere il rifugio nella sua natura incontaminata». Scott Warren, uno dei volontari, professore all’Arizona State University, è coinvolto in un processo separato per aver ospitato i migranti irregolari. Se sarà giudicato colpevole, rischierà una condanna fino a 20 anni di carcere.

title: L’ultra destra spagnola finanziata dagli esuli iraniani. Oltre un milione nelle casse di Vox
content: Prima gli spagnoli, ma con i soldi iraniani. Vox, il partito di estrema destra, in forte ascesa dopo l’exploit elettorale in Andalusia, è stato finanziato per anni dagli iscritti del Consiglio Nazionale della Resistenza Iraniana, il movimento degli esuli anti regime. L’inchiesta pubblicata dal País imbarazza non poco la formazione nazionalista, anche perché il Cnri è stato, fino al 2014 nella lista nera delle organizzazioni terroristiche degli Stati Uniti e dell’Unione europea. Secondo quanto raccontato, con molti dettagli, dal quotidiano, gli oppositori del regime degli ayatollah avrebbero finanziato non soltanto la campagna elettorale per le Europee del 2014 (l’80 per cento del totale), ma anche tutte le spese correnti: la sede della Calle Diego de León nel prestigioso quartiere di Salamanca a Madrid, le bollette e gli stipendi di impiegati e dirigenti a cominciare da quello del leader Santiago Abascal, allora segretario generale. Il legame tra la formazione spagnola e gli iraniani ha contorni oscuri, ma l’origine pare chiara. Tutto nasce dai rapporti internazionali dell’ex vicepresidente del Parlamento europeo, Alejo Vidal-Quadras, il quale uscendo dal Partito Popolare, ha contribuito a fondare Vox. Vidal Quadrads diede molta visibilità al Consiglio della Resistenza, organizzando convegni e iniziative di solidarietà in tutta Europa. La gratitudine degli iraniani non tarda a manifestarsi: il primo bonifico, arriva il 17 dicembre del 2013, ovvero la data in cui la sigla Vox viene registrata nel registro dei partiti politici del ministero dell’Interno. Da lì in poi il flusso è continuo, fatto di donazioni dei singoli iscritti, per un totale di 971.890 euro tra il 2013 e la primavera del 2014. Il leader Abascal, «era al corrente di tutto», spiega Vidal Quadrads. Queste entrate sarebbero state dichiarate, ma la Corte dei Conti spagnola nega. La legge vieta ai partiti il finanziamento estero.

title: The Moon, Dogs, and the mysterious Truffle
content:
“The moon must be believed”. Try cutting a pine tree during full moon: the worms will eat it. Even grafts must be made during the first days of the moon, otherwise they fail. Humanity has come to plan trips to Mars, yet when it comes to the white truffle of Alba, we still rely on the moon. That same moon which, according to Italian poet Cesare Pavese, “must be believed, beyond doubt”. We don’t know where truffles are born, we are not able to cultivate them nor can we reproduce them. Only the nose of a dog can lead us to the king of mushrooms. Better if during the night – even better on a full moon night- the four-pawed hunter guides his master at the foot of this or that tree, away from prying eyes. The perfumed mystery of this strange fungus growing underground is still intact, unperturbed by all evolution it stands solid on a single certainty, that of the plate and the palate, as well as that of the wallet. And it is precisely this secret and this certainty that is celebrated for the 88th time in Alba with the Truffle Fair, the first to have crossed borders and become international. 
Gourmets from all over the world mark these dates: from October 6 to November 25 Alba brings to light its most hidden jewel, the tuber magnatum pico that since the 1930s has been carrying its captivating scent around the world, along with the good name of Langhe and Roero. The official inauguration will be opened by representatives of the Italian cities that have obtained, like Alba, the recognition of Creative Cities by UNESCO: Rome, Bologna, Milan, Turin, Parma, Pesaro, Carrara and Fabriano. It will be the start of an intense autumn: the strength of the Alba Fair lies in its ability to transform itself into an event that goes beyond the traditional gastronomic appointment, offering visitors exhibitions, cooking shows, folklore and experiential paths. It is enough to mention, the solo art show by Valerio Berruti , which tells the story of the recent film project of the artist from Alba with a sound-track by Ludovico Einaudi. Or the exhibition curated by the Ceretto family: and the large group show  to the Ferrero Foundation.
Those who let themselves be guided by their noses will inevitably arrive at the Palatartufo set up in the heart of the city, where every weekend in October and November, the World Truffle Market takes place. The air is filled with truffle scent and optimism. 2018 might be classified as “the year of the white truffle”. To speak positively of the season just started are the truffle hunters from all over Italy who, already in spring have begun rubbing their hands as they watched the rain pour from the sky with unusual abundance.So, after a 2017 ranked as “annus horribilis” for the few products found underground and the prices that skyrocketed (never below 450 euros per 100 gr -3.5 oz.), white truffle lovers can expect a rosier and more affordable 2018. A dish in a restaurant - with a of 6-7 grams truffle “grate” - might “just” cost 25 euros. But there is still time: the search for white nuggets will continue until January 31. On the other hand, visitors will be spoilt for choice by the endless types of dish, even if the advice is to taste the truffle on courses that tend to be neutral, able to enhance the articulated, intense and overwhelming scent: raw meat beaten with a knife, fried egg, white tajarin (local type of pasta) and fondue. With its bizarre and counter-current character, the underground mushroom grows in the shade of centuries-old oaks, immersed in calcareous or clayey soil. But to make a truffle, you need a tree, this tree must be preserved, protected along with the fragile natural environment that characterizes the truffle areas. This is why the “Save The Truffle” project, which brings together 300 wine producers from Langhe and Roero, is so important. The initiative fosters a symbiosis between Vineyard and Truffle and proposes the planting of truffle friendly plants on the edges of the vineyards to interrupt the monoculture and restore the agricultural landscape to its original diversity. The goal is to obtain great wines and excellent truffles from the same land: can one desire for more?

title: Rome: Illegal villas with no sewers on archeological finds
content: In Ardea (Rome), there is a 6km road stretch where everything found on its left side is illegal. Everything: houses, villas, shops, companies, garages. There is no regular electrical connection. No drinking water. There are no sewers either. The toilets are discharged into the fields, or directly into the nearby stream, which in turn ends up in the sea. Which, in fact, has a ban on bathing. It's wasteland.It’s a ghostly neighborhood, where everything is illegal and taxes do not exist, it is called Salzare. No one knows exactly how big it is. The traffic police don’t go in there. “I only have 52 agents, most of them are women, I can’t put anyone’s life in danger,” says Mario Savarese, the mayor of Ardea. We are using a drone to map out all the illegal buildings. I told the technicians to move fast: some of the residents are armed, they might shoot down the drones”. There was a time when Ardea was famous for Luchino Visconti’s beach house, also an illegally built villa. To tell the truth, the Italian world-famous director’s villa became famous because  mafia boss Frank Coppola, known as “Frank three fingers” for he lost 2 cracking a safe, also lived there. And yes, the construction-development history of Ardea from the 50s to the present day is now so compromised that it already includes three or four building amnesties. This small town is home of six totally illegal districts. Some houses are so close to the stream that when it rains heavily, they end up under a meter and a half of water. But it is the Salzare residents who have it  worst for soon they will become stateless, because they occupy land that was previously state-owned and now belongs to the municipality, which certainly can not issue new identity cards for non-existent addresses. Officially, in the town of Ardea there are 40 thousand houses, 23 thousand resident families, 8 thousand requests for amnesty under evaluation, and 300 orders of demolition already decreed by final judgment yet never executed. And, let’s be clear: that 6 km roadside has not been included in this calculation. The seven terraced buildings with swimming pools found in the ghostly neighborhood of Salzare, were supposed to be the city’s flagship, yet they were built over archaeological finds. And they too, at least in theory, should all be demolished, “almost 90 percent of the houses on the beach are unauthorized and should be bulldozed,” according to the mayor.The mayor, a retired computer entrepreneur belonging to the five star movement: “I came here with the best intentions. I wanted to bring back some legality. But it’s impossible”. I’m not giving up, but I must admit I’m desperate”. The City is in economic disarray. Net of the titanic tax evasion, it receives 31 million euros a year in cash. That makes up for 551 euros of annual expenditure per capita. Not even close to enough: in Ardea there is no money for essential services. Schools are missing. Children play in the garbage. The city centre is in such an abandoned state that even the police don’t show up. In their last report, they asked the mayor to take away the licenses of some merchants: “Despite the arrests, the situation has worsened. The population is now exasperated. At present, there is still a great deal of social degradation throughout the area, so much so that this location, which used to be a prestigious residential area, is now considered a hotbed for alcoholics, criminals, illegal immigrants, drug addicts and drug dealers. Such individuals are found in the most disparate psychophysical conditions”. The number of unauthorized building is growing. The last illegal construction was blocked in October. “Those who can no longer live in Rome, look for a house here,” says the mayor. “What we need is a complete map of all the irregularities, but it is difficult to send the bulldozers. The only demolition that took place was in 2013: one of the seven buildings was built on archaeological finds, the City spent 450 thousand euros on that demolition. A figure totally beyond our reach. The 7 - now 6 - remaining villa-complex cover the horizon. The sea is not visible. The beach is filthy. The roads to get there are a rosary of holes. A local woman: “They took the whole coast”. An old man, “Those little houses over there. They’re camorra stuff. People don’t even come close because they’re afraid”. The procurator of the area says he is “discouraged,” adding that “We have 1800 demolitions already ordered with a final sentence. But no one sends the bulldozers in. It’s the same old story. There is no doubt that the problem is about political consensus. And the mayors’ answer is always the same: they have no money”. Thirty kilometers north of this unlawful neighborhood, in a town called Rocca di Papa, the “Pro House” committee was born. That is: “pro illegal house” and it counts about one thousand members. The president - owner of a small villa built in 2003, declares “It’s the rule around here. The mayors have always reassured us. All of us. They gave us the residence, they supplied us with electricity, then water. And now, what are they thinking? To treat us like criminals and destroy everything?”. The town planning map of Rocca di Papa stopped in 1976, when the residents were 5,000. Today they are 18,000. (Translated by Anna Martinelli)

title: Naples, Teen prodigies win US robot contest but the school has no money for the trip
content: “We’re already happy like this. Yet of course, if we were able to compete on an equal footing with others...”. Davide Di Pierro, 17 years old, who is doing a pretty good job in hiding his bitterness, describes as if it were ordinary administration what he and his working group have done so far at the “Augusto Righi” technical and industrial secondary institute in Naples. That is, ranking second (for now) in the high school tournament “Zero robotics”, aerospace competition organized by MIT and NASA, which was attended by over three hundred schools around the world. Together with two other students of the same age - Mauro D’Alò and Luigi Picarella - and professors Salvatore Pelella and Ciro Melcarne, for 6 months they committed themselves to the “mission” chosen by NASA for this edition. A real picnic: programming the coupling of a robot-satellite from the ISS (the orbiting space station well known to Italians for the performances of Luca Parmitano, Samantha Cristoforetti and Paolo Nespoli). “We started working in our homes, then from September we continued in our school, in the afternoon, but we brought computers from home because they were more reliable” Davide explains, who only the day before yesterday launched a sort of appeal during a local science conference: “It is not easy for Italian schools, especially in the South of Italy, to be able to compete with schools of the great world economic giants without using the appropriate facilities and without money, not even enough to go to the final”. Forge of talent, in previous years, the “Righi” technical high school already reached the final stages of the race but only in one case students were able to leave for the U.S. “It was when the families of the students participated in the expenses. Last year, though we were second, we were stuck home. And I have the feeling that even this we won’t be able to see the fruit of our work,” Davide adds. To sum their story up: they have proven they can master NASA technology, they have beaten the competition of Australian, German, Russian and American schools (sponsored by no less than Apple and Microsoft), but they are left stranded because there are no funds for the trip (a few thousand euros) to the States. In Italy, country of the brain drain and in Naples, city of the St. Gennaro’s miracle, irony feels like a bittersweet gateway: “We are close to the holidays, maybe Santa Claus, or la Befana (a mythical old woman who delivers gifts to children throughout Italy on Epiphany Eve) will figure something out ...”, a teacher says on the sidelines of the conference, in a vain attempt to exorcise the despair. Meanwhile, as we wait for Santa Claus to do what public institutions should do, the brilliant young students illustrate to the conference participants their year-long-“feeling” with the space competition created in 2009 thanks to astronaut Greg Chamitoff, a challenge initially limited to U.S. schools and then extended to the whole planet with different formulas (there is also a European edition that was organized by the Polytechnic of Turin with the Italian Space Agency). Davide, on the other hand, calmly smiles: “As I told you, we’re already happy like that, it’s clear that it would have been nice to take part in the final, to be there in direct connection with the space station, to see the satellite moving thanks to our algorithms...”. Yeah, that would be nice. And since we’re struggling with starry skies, why not make a wish? Which Davide says out loud: “Obviously, I wish to go and compete in Boston in January, and then...”. Then what? “Well, I’d love to meet Italian Astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti”.

title: Palermo conference on Libya in disarray
content:
Curiosity tinged with pragmatism, unwavering hope, some laughter, and a little disappointment that begs the question now of “what will happen in Libya?”. Italy’s efforts to host the summit on stabilizing Libya after its seven-year-old conflict appeared to fall flat Tuesday, as organizers on the second and final day of the meeting in Sicily failed to even confirm whether representatives of the main factions were attending.Of course, Libyans were not waiting at the edge of their seat watching the developments in Palermo in front of the TV, as the head of the Libyan National Army, Khalifa Haftar’s made jokes about diplomacy. They had other things on their mind. In Tripoli, for example, bank clerks were dealing with their usual queues and storefronts with their usual dips in supply, all while the administrative machine continued to turn at its characteristic speed.
In the cafes as in houses in the Libyan capital–as it so often does between the tribes and the rest of the country–any mention settlement between the country’s warring factions goes in one ear and out the next. “We’ve had a lot of conferences, our political situation is complicated, too many people want to be bosses or want to become president. I think we still need time to mature. That’s why I fear that not much will come out of Palermo,” says Mustafa Barouni, mayor of Zintan.Zintan is considered by some to be a city-state, and they played a large part in overthrowing Gaddafi during the Libyan Revolution. Barouni expresses a certain disappointment at not being invited to the Palermo conference. “Without a doubt the four leaders who have represented the country are well-known figures and have strength in the field, no doubt they could, indeed can, contribute to the solution of the Libyan crisis, but they are not the only ones,” he said. This sentiment is echoed by another city-state, Misurata, also disappointed by the fact that its main spokesman, vice president Ahmed Maetig, wasn’t invited either to attend the summit. In reality, Zintan has its sights set on something else; an electoral body along the lines of the national reconciliation conference in early 2019 that U.N. Envoy to Libya Ghassan Salame announced last week, and which will set the stage for nation-wide elections in Libya. “It would be nice to hold them in 2019, but I do not think it’s possible, we’re not ready,” Barouni says of the 2019 elections. One thing he hopes will emerge from the Palermo summit is the awareness of Fayez al Sarraj’s government to “give support to local administrations because they are the only guarantors of the territory”.
There are those who expect a step forward from the conference on security in the capital: “We must encourage as much as possible the transition to a regular force and facilitate the exit of the militia,” says Saad Hamali, a spokesman of the 7th Brigade (a.k.a Kanyat or Kani brigade, from Tarhuna, a city some 65 km to the southeast of Tripoli), the so-called “insurgents” who clashed against a coalition of brigades in Tripoli earlier this year in August. “The situation had become unbearable, in the suburbs and in the outskirts there was no water, gas or light due to the cuts imposed by certain factions that control Tripoli. There was no bread and there was no cash, the militias have humiliated Libya and it’s time to change things.” For the Tarhuna Brigade there are also rival faction that have developed and sustained relationships with illegal migrant and fuel traffickers: “That is why the solution of the problem is in everyone’s interest, even in Italy.”Some draw on the work of General Paolo Serra, former former senior security advisor to UNSMIL, like Husam Najjair or “Irish Sam” (the Dubliner who fought Gaddafi) and wrote about his experience in a book, “The Lions of the Tripoli Brigade”. “To combat organized crime, we need to start with the work of Serra and create institutional security forces, so we can re-establish Tripoli.” Others underline the socio-cultural DNA of Libyan civil society, explaining that there are at least 120 tribes in the country, and neither of its four leaders are able to represent them. Ashraf Shah, who was part of the Libyan political dialogue from which the Skhirat agreements were born, argues that the inclusive position of the UN is reasonable “but the people do not support those leaders”.
Thus the “bottom-up” solution that Ghassan Salame announced is the National Conference to be held in the first weeks of 2019. The subsequent electoral process should commence in the spring of 2019, Salame told the Security Council. The conference would gather over 200 representatives of Libyan civil society, and the initiative is welcomed by the Libyan tribes, including those of the South, who occupied periphery positions on the Palermo stage and eagerly await the release of strategic surveillance plans of the Ghat border. The project is key to the local and regional dynamics, because from Fezzan there are threats of factions of the Awlad Suleyman aimed at subverting Tripoli, destabilizing Ubari and the tribal balance.“For months and months that project, which would have put the French intervention in south of Libya in deadlock, has been recklessly halted,” explains Agenfor International, an NGO that conducts global analysis on human rights issues. “All the trafficking flows from the south and there the semi-nomadic Tuareg people have always favored Italy, so the Rome-Tripoli axis is more than just a strategic asset.”

title: Photos, clothes and bones give a name to the migrants who died at sea
content:
At first glance, he was supposed to be 18. Then one of the doctors took a closer look at the iliac crest. It hadn’t not yet fused, as it happens in adults: the boy was younger, maybe sixteen. Then, they moved on to the teeth. The second and third molars were easily extracted. The third molar’s root was just beginning to form. Fourteen years old. They stripped him. A jacket, waistcoat, shirt, jeans. Inside the jacket they felt something. They unsowed the inside pocket. There was a report card written in Arabic and French. Mathematiques, sciences physiques. It must have been the most precious thing he had, to sew it into his jacket. It was his pass for a better future in Europe. Cristina Cattaneo was born in Casale Monferrato, Piedmont region in the North of Italy. She is Professor of Forensic Medicine at the University of Milan and director of Labanof, the Laboratory of Anthropology and Forensic Dentistry. Her job, one of many, is trying to give a name to the nameless dead. She does it for the simple reason that all the wisdom of the world was written at the origins of humankind, and all the wisdom about the dead lies in the tears of Priam who asks Achilles the body of his son Hector to give him burial. It was already all written there. We are receiving numerous requests from Eritreans and Syrians, a colleague of the Red Cross told her one day, because they are waiting for the arrival of relatives and no longer know anything, whether they are alive or dead. For years people have died crossing the Mediterranean, their corpses lying at the bottom of the sea, or buried under nameless gravestones. Since 2001, more than thirty thousand people have died. No one has ever thought of doing what is normally done: give them an identity and give an answer to their mothers, sons and daughters, grandparents, tell them they can still hope to wait, or can put their heart at peace. 
When the group was formed in 2013, people began to arrive from all over Europe. A woman searched through the photos in the database: she was looking for her brother she had heard two hours before he embarked in Libya; she froze, her eyes stuck on fragments of paper with some phone numbers written on it. It’s his handwriting, she said, this is his four and this is his seven, and she broke down crying. Another woman arrived with an envelope with the strand of hair of an Eritrean friend, who had no news of her son and hoped that the hair would be used for DNA. One man was sure that his sister had drowned, but if I don’t have a death certificate I can’t adopt my nephew, he said, he is a child and was left in Somalia. Why are you doing all this? A friend asked Cristina. Why don’t you throw a wreath of flowers into the sea, and move on? If you suspected that your daughter was on a plane that had crashed into the sea, Cristina replied, would you throw a wreath of flowers or would you try to know? Well, if you put it that way… her friend said. Then The Barge sank. It was April 18, 2015, in the sea of Sicily. More or less a thousand-people died on that boat, which could contain a hundred to say the least. For two months, in a Navy hangar in Melilli, Syracuse, Cristina and the others worked on the filing of 525 bodies. There were whole bodies, like the one of the boy who had sewn inside the jacket a bag with the land of his country, Eritrea. There were Korans, Buddhist rosaries, an Orthodox cross. There were skulls without bodies and bodies without skulls. There were dozens of small hand bones alone in that ossuary. There was the tiny round tooth of a six-year-old boy. There were library tiles, photos of smiling groups, sweatshirts from Real Madrid. There was the hold of the Barge in which they had to enter, once it had been beached: it was “a carpet of human bodies”, “stretched across the entire area of the hold, about sixty square meters wide, almost all face down, some in fetal position, many swollen because of the rot, made more human by hats, gloves, sweaters and shoes. The dead speak better than the living, says Cristina. You can go to the survivors, listen to them, but they will never be able to explain like the dead do. “I plunged my arm protected by a suit almost up to my armpit: I felt at least four layers of bodies”. We Italians have been the first to set up a team that would do for “their” dead the same as we do for our own. All the institutions have collaborated with the due commitment, and the first results are arriving. The mother of the child left in Somalia was identified, the kid was adopted by his uncle whom he joined abroad. Others are no longer waiting for whatever news, now they know, and can pray for the soul of their father and sister. The Barge, Cristina says, should be a national monument: it has nothing to do with what one thinks of immigration and welcoming, it has nothing to do with what we think of human beings and their dignity, when they are alive and when they are dead. (All this is told in Naufraghi senza volto (Faceless Shipwreckers), by Cristina Cattaneo, one hundred and ninety-two pages of hard work, torment and hope in bookshop from Thursday for Cortina publisher).

title: Telecom Italia appoints Luigi Gubitosi as CEO
content: The embattled phone company, Telecom Italia (TIM), appointed Luigi Gubitosi as CEO on Sunday, after his predecessor, Amos Genish, was ousted last Tuesday over alleged disagreements with board members over the company’s strategy.The former Merrill Lynch banker was chosen because of his prodigious experience in telecom and media. He was the former head of Italian telecommunications group Wind, the state-owned television network RAI, and the state-appointed commissioner of airline Alitalia. He succeeds Amos Genish, who had been pursuing a three-year turnaround plan. Genish will remain on the board and said he would seek investor support to hold an extraordinary shareholder meeting to contest the sudden changes. He told agencies on Sunday that it should be up to all shareholders to decide such a drastic change and not just a limited group of people.Gubito’s appointment is considered a win for the company’s activist investor Elliott Management Corp., which wrested control of TIM earlier in May from its other principal investor, Vivendi.At the top of the agenda for Elliot is the creation of a single broadband infrastructure company, combining TIM’s network with that of smaller, state-backed broadband rival, Open Fiber.Vivendi voted against Gubitosi, a spokesman for the French media group said. TIM stocks have declined by some 36 percent in the last year after Elliott’s takeover, making the company worth a little over over 10 billion euros. TIM has been weighed down by net debt of 25 billion euros and heavy pension liabilities. The carrier hasn’t paid a dividend on its ordinary shares since 2013 and must now also shoulder heavy investments in new networks. Gubitosi is considered influential in certain of Rome’s political circles, which may work in his favor with the Italian government, which is pushing for a single fixed network as a way to boost investment in fiber, Bloomberg reported. Shares in the company rose by 4 percent this morning.

title: Venetian “Hunted” island for sale, yet nobody wants it
content: To buy Poveglia, in the surthern side of the Venetian lagoon, aka the world’s most hunted island (local legends have the spirits and ghosts of the dead of the plagues roaming there) the highest offer was just 513 thousand euros for a 50-year-concession. And that was in 2014. To place the offer, even in the wake of rallies against the “sale to privates”, was the entrepreneur Luigi Brugnaro who, the following year, became mayor of Venice. The State Property Office rejected the offer considering it “insufficient” and those 7 hectares in one of the World’s most famous lagoons, the same that until the post-war period served both as a maritime quarantine station for those suffering the plague and a mental hospital, since then have remained on the lists of public assets to be “enhanced”, i.e. sold to privates. Like the Island of Poveglia, a thousand-other small yet great treasures of Italy.Poveglia, together with the castle of Gradisca d’Isonzo in the province of Gorizia, and Casa Nappi in Loreto, a few steps away from the Sanctuary, were some of the high-spots that the Italian government had included in 2014 in the Stability Act with the intention to collect 500 million a year between 2014 and 2016. However, the online auctions, the first ever attempted in Italy, immediately turned out to be a flop: few offers and inadequate prices. Even today, the over 7300 square meters of the fortress of Gradisca await an investor, while Poveglia island (after a series of interventions to secure the ancient buildings) is expected a new call for tenders by the autumn of this year. Only for the property of Casa Nappi, according to the website of the State Property Office, there is talk of negotiations “in the process of being defined”.In Italy, operations of disposal and enhancement of public buildings have always proved to be very, too complex. And the budget objectives are light years away from expectations. Nowadays the anti-establishment and Populist government, to shore up its accounts in the eyes of Brussels, is counting on 18 billion from divestments in 2019 alone. A goal that all experts in the field consider “absolutely unreachable” given that in recent years it has not gone beyond a billion - at most - a year. In the past, those who have given a chance to this type of business explain that “the market cannot absorb more than that”. Also because the real estate - the ones truly interesting for the market - are not many: we are talking about 50 billion euros of real estate in the State Property Office out of a total of 60, the remaining 10 are low value assets which might find buyers, provided however that they can rent to the same Public administration the buildings. But in addition to producing an immediate explosion in public spending, since for Brussels these are “sale and lease” operations, the proceeds could not even be put to debt reduction. Over the years, the holes in the water have been countless. Even today, Invimit the website of the State Property Office, and “Invest in Italy” portal, are full of offers. Of the more than 230 properties that were still on display two years ago, most are still there. Among the most valuable assets only the hotel “la Lama” next to the Fuksas Cloud at Eur in Rome, paid 50 million euros and now part of the Hilton chain, and the former Innocenti Hospital in Bologna were placed, the rest are still left hanging. There are several ongoing negotiations, but the bulk remains unsold. The Bankitalia offices in Imperia and Gorizia, the Palazzo degli esami in Rome and Piazza d’Armi in Milan, the Terme Berzieri in Salsomaggiore and the Grand Hotel in San Pellegrino are still waiting to find a buyer. In Turin, the former Avio at the Lingotto, the Saluzzo and La Marmora barracks and more than 16,000 square metres of the Region’s headquarters overlooking Piazza Castello. “The State no longer has any assets to put in income investments. Now wealth lies in the territories”, Invimit CEO Elisabetta Spitz explained at a conference a few days ago, when she estimated 300 billion assets. It’s a shame, however, that not even the municipalities are able to make money since not even 1% of their disposal plans follow through.

title: Banksy solo exhibit opens in Milan
content: When you put Banksy under the limelight of museum walls–make a show of his revolution, frame his provocation–it’s not long before his work changes tone, and his satire loses strength.These are but two side effects of street art distorted by the market, on display for the first time ever at Mudec (Museo delle Culture in Milan), an Italian public museum. Banksy is the elusive British street-artist whose identity remains famously unknown, yet his signature style is so distinct that he doesn’t need another identity. The show, which runs until April 14 is not authorized by the artist. Still it comprises about 80 works, including paintings and prints, alongside objects, photographs, videos and memorabilia. And yet it’s not misappropriation. The artist has famously refused to get lodged into a system (he opposes the capitalist validation of art) and has said before “I don’t charge people to see my art unless there’s a fairground wheel”. And it was only a few weeks ago when the artist made international headlines by partially shredding one of his works at a London auction house (and people are still wondering whether the auction house knew about his plan). At the same time, Banksy’s work has been of increasing interest the major art dealers and collectors. Contrary to what the artist would probably wish for, the value of his work is increasing simultaneously: “Girl with the Balloon” doubled from its initial sale price of 1.3 million dollars after it was partially shredded (now re-christened as a new work, “Love is in the Bin” (2018)). Earlier this month as well, U.S. street artist Ron English bought a Banksy for $730,000, and is planning to whitewash it in protest of the market’s co-opting of street art, Artsy reported.Banksy exhibit in Russia This August when the writer found out that a ticketed exhibition in Moscow had been curated of his work he said: “Hmm – not sure I’m the best person to complain about people putting up pictures without getting permission.” Today’s exhibition opening of his work almost warrants his participation in some strange way, perhaps with an ironic drawing to reply, a sentence, a slaughter, a joke. Inside the museum there are the works that made him famous but he is not there because he continues to trick us. His art can be put on display, be appreciated, admired, evoke an era, steal smiles, increase in interest but it’s always in flux and it does not matter how much passion, attention, respect goes into the preparation.The “Girl With The Balloon” became larger than life and the paper shredder was not a special effect, but rather a warning, a sort of “there will be no other Banksy than me”. Seen on a wall, above a window, in the air, it has impact. It moves you. And while a guided tour can be interesting, that exact intention is lost–it becomes a second-hand emotion, a package already discarded. Inside, yes, there is his style: The story of a boy who likely grew up in Bristol among the punks; someone who brought “guerilla art” out of the alleys and who knows how to keep it alive and relevant; and someone who excels at refusing and enjoying fame at the same time–a very unusual combination.Banksy is not the first artist to reject the art market (the Dadas did that before him), nor the first artist to destroy his own work (in the 50s Rauschenberg erased a de Kooning drawing with the sole purpose of reproducing it). He’s not the first artist to mock Queen Elizabeth (we had the Sex Pistols for that) nor is he the first graffiti artist to earn widespread acclaim (Keith Haring came before him), but he is the only artist to continuously evade those museum walls, unless he’s inviting himself in there in the first place. It’s impossible to recreate the moods and emotions of his art even if the walls at Mudec resemble streets and the captions remind us yellow post-its. Banksy is an industry and an idea. The description of a success.An original version of this article first appeared in Italian in La Stampa. This piece has been edited for clarity.

title: Queen Leda and swan-Zeus discovered having sex in “exceptional” Pompeii Fresco
content: After unearthing in May the headless skeleton of Pompeii’s “unluckiest” man whose skull probably lied crushed under a boulder, six months later, in a small bedroom of the most famous archeological site of the world, the portrait of Leda, the beautiful queen of Sparta, was discovered. Could it get any better? Yes, the fresco depicts the queen while being “seduced” by Jupiter, the king of Gods who - in order to possess her - turned himself into a swan. Explicit and sensual, rich in colors and nuances that underline the high quality of execution, this large fresco behind the hall of a big house in Via del Vesuvio. An “exceptional and unique” discovery, the director of the Archaeological Park Massimo Osanna exclusively anticipates to Ansa news agency. The deep red of the background, the pink that makes the beauty of Leda explosive and the white palette of the swan seducing her as she looks on - have been preserved magnificently from the eruption of Mount Vesuvius nearly 2,000 years ago.“The fresco - explains Osanna - was discovered during restoration work, as part of one of the EU-funded projects for the rearrangement of Pompeii that are taking place in the Royal V of the Roman citadel. The domus home of the exceptional discovery overlooked the eastern side of via del Vesuvio. In the entrance of that same house, he specifies, last summer a fresco of Priapus in the act of weighing his penis, image similar to the well-known one that decorates the entrance to the famous Villa dei Vetti, had been discovered. In this case it is a finding of particular importance, the director Osanna emphasizes, precisely because of the workmanship of Leda’s portrait, which is extremely special and “different from all the others so far found in other houses. In the Roman town, he explains, the reference to the Greek myth of Leda and the swan is “quite widespread”, but it had never been found “with this explicit sensual iconography, which seems to look - the archaeologist hypothesizes - at the sculptural model of Timothy”, an important Greek sculptor of the 4th century BC.Flirty and rather licentious, Leda’s oblique gaze seems to meet the eyes of those who enter the room, the portrait of the house in Via del Vesuvio was, Hosanna points out, in a cubicle, i.e. a bedroom which was accessed immediately after passing the arched opening with the Priapus fresco. But who was the owner? Still unknown, yet Osanna’s most probable hypothesis is that the domus belonged to “ former slave who was anxious to elevate his social status through references to high-level cultural myths”. More cannot certainly be known. Precisely because of the site’s security needs (the new excavations are born precisely from the works of preservation and for securing the archeological site) the other rooms of this rich mansion cannot be brought to light. So much so that, in order to save and protect the two splendid frescoes, the director anticipates, “technicians are evaluating whether to move them to a different location in order to preserve them and exhibit them to the public”.

title: Quality test for the heroic Prosecco Vineyards
content:
It’s easy to say Prosecco. Everyone knows it, everyone drinks it. But the record-breaking sparkling wine, that has beaten all competitors by millions of bottles, is not all the same. There is a great difference between label and label, and even more between the bubbles of the hills and those coming from the vast plains that stretch between the Veneto and Friuli regions. The complexity of the Prosecco production and the differences between the denominations are well represented by an ideal pyramid at the base of which we find Prosecco Doc, almost half a billion bottles produced in a very large territory that includes nine provinces between the two regions. 
In the central part of this hypothetical pyramid there is the Prosecco Superiore Docg of Asolo, while at the top there is the Conegliano Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore Docg, the sparkling wine produced on the hills between Conegliano and Valdobbiadene, a small area of Treviso set between Venice and the Dolomites that represents the expression of the best quality of Prosecco. The high-end of the pyramid, we will find it in the refined selections of the Rive and in the Superiore of Cartizze Docg, a sort of grand cru of Conegliano Valdobbiadene. 
In the 15 municipalities included in the Conegliano Valdobbiadene denomination, the production of wine dates back to ancient times while, over the centuries, winemakers have shaped the landscape creating a unique landscape, with vineyards that embroider the hills. A natural and cultural landscape so beautiful that it has been nominated to become a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Here the cultivation of the vine is defined as heroic, because it is difficult and tiring for the slopes can reach 70% thus demanding an almost exclusively manual labor. The harvesting of the grapes, on the hills between Conegliano and Valdobbiadene, ended a few days ago. “It was an excellent harvest, it will be drunk very well around the world - says Gianfranco Aneri, enlightened wine producer and marketing magician. In our three farms, we have recorded a harvest 10% higher than last year, and despite the quantity, the quality has also grown higher. We will produce about 400,000 bottles of vintage (millesimato) Prosecco Docg: a significant number, but not a huge one. Our customers are selected, we don’t need to widen too much”. Aneri’s message is clear: “Prosecco Docg has a downhill path ahead if it continues to focus on quality. If, on the other hand, entrepreneurs think they can take advantage of the promising moment in the market by excessively expanding the quantity, they will pay for it in the next few years”. The producer who had the former President of the United States, Barack Obama, toast with their wines, ought to know when to say no: “In England, where the sale of Prosecco has recently dropped, there is an important chain of restaurants that has asked me to supply 1 million bottles at the price of 2.5 pounds. I replied: “But besides the bottle, the cork and the label, do you also want the wine?””. 
Today the average price of a bottle of Prosecco Docg wholesale, excluding VAT, is between 5 and 8 euros. The production of Conegliano Valdobbiadene in 2017 was 94 million bottles: 42% go abroad, with Germany, Switzerland, the United Kingdom, Benelux and the USA in the front row. “This year, thanks to a very generous harvest, we will be able to grow a little more - says Innocente Nardi, president of the Consortium of Conegliano Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore -. But ours is a ripe denomination, which knows its limits and its qualities: the sacrifices are many, those are some harsh slopes, we break our backs up there. Now it seems that even consumers know how to recognize the way the Prosecco system works out”. The price of the vineyards has also risen, reaching 300-500 thousand euros per hectare, without counting the millionaire quotations of Cartizze. “Our denomination - Nardi explains - extends over 8 thousand hectares of vineyards, cultivated by more than 3300 families that express an authentic know-how. Within strict boundaries, there is a great fragmentation and a strong bond between the winemakers with the land. Not for everyone, however, this bond automatically means environmental protection. So much so that the demands to ban the use of pesticides are increasingly pressing. “The environmental issue, in my opinion, is poorly expressed - he concludes -. Anyone who knows Conegliano Valdobbiadene knows that we are a leading lab for sustainability. We have been making innovative decisions since 2011 and from 1 January 2019, glyphosate can no longer be used. We want to be at the forefront, every incentive to improve is a good thing, but wars are useless”.

title: Farewell to the last master of Italian cinema, Bernardo Bertolucci died at  age  77
content: Bernardo Bertolucci, Oscar-winning director, screenwriter and film producer, died at 77 years old. Originally from Parma, he had been ill for a long time. One of the most representative and internationally known Italian film directors, his great notoriety  arrived in 1972, with a movie that - at the time - became synonymous with scandal: Last tango in Paris, starring Marlon Brando and Maria Schneider, which was released briefly in the theater, and then sent to the stake in Italy for it was considered pornographic, only to come back restyled in theaters this year. From being censored to winning 9 Oscars - including best director and best picture for  The Last Emperor - Bertolucci’s film history (16 movies) has been marked by experimental cinema, art-house cinema, popular movies, low-budget production up to Hollywood mega ones. The last great master of the 20th century held both the abilities to describe small Italian provincial life, and stun the world with his international poetic visions which worth him the Golden Lion for Lifetime Achievement at the 64th Venice International Film Festival, and in 2011 the Honorary Golden Palm at the 64th Cannes Film Festival.Son of a poet, he was raised in the cinema world by Pier Paolo Pasolini, to whom he became assistant director at the age of 20, in 1961, the following year he made his debut as a director with La Comare secca (The Grim Reaper) based on a short story by Pasolini himself, and won two years later, with Before the Revolution, the undisputed fame of best author of a new generation of filmmakers in which creative inspiration goes hand in hand with civil commitment. He also worked together with Spaghetti western director Sergio Leone, for whom he wrote together with Dario Argento, the screenplay of Once Upon a Time in the West, he acquired international stature in 1970 with two masterpieces: Strategy of the Spider and The Conformist from the story of his friend Alberto Moravia. Two years later he scandalized the whole world with the above mentioned erotic drama Last tango in Paris, and the famous butter scene, and in 1976, he consolidated his poetic soul, strongly tied to his native land, and his international soul, bound to the American sense of cinema understood as a marvellous wonder, signing the two-act movie Novecento, (1900) with Robert De Niro and Gérard Depardieu. Adopted by Hollywood, in the 80s and 90s Bertolucci produced his exotic trilogy, starting with the nine Oscars  epic biopic The Last Emperor, the desperate journey in the Moroccan desert of The Sheltering Sky with John Malkovich e Debra Winger, and the search of inner peace of the Little Buddha starring Keanu Reeves. 2003 was the year of the romantic movie The Dreamers, while 2012 was when Bernardo Bertolucci  directed his last film, Io e te (Me and You).

title: Italian Aristocratic family at war for world’s largest private collection of marble statues
content: The court has blocked the expatriation of the Torlonia family’s works of art. The world’s largest private collection - worth nearly two billion euros - is at stake: 620 marbles, a villa and a painting gallery.Not even Berlusconi had succeeded in unlocking the 620 marbles of inestimable value of Torlonia, the largest private collection in the world, which disappeared in the basement of a building in Via della Lungara where, in place of the Museum, in the 1970s, mini apartments popped up. But the death of Prince Alexander, and the fierce hereditary war that followed, has rekindled a beacon on this story and on the statues that over the years have not only been collecting dust in a cellar but have run the serious risk of “emigrating” overseas. But now, thanks to the heir of the title, Carlo Torlonia, the marbles, the picture gallery and a large part of the family heritage have been seized by the court. A “fratricidal” hereditary war which sees Prince Charles on one side and his three siblings, Paola, Francesca and Giulio, on the other one. A huge patrimony that includes not only the art collections but also Villa Torlonia (formerly Villa Albani) that was inhabited by Benito Mussolini, and several other jaw-dropping buildings. Heirs at war, fighting not only for an immense fortune, but also for their last name, (a piece of Italy’s history), along with the fate of works of art that are a private good yet also a good for humanity. And it probably on this line that the judge yesterday proved Carlo Torlonia right as he saw the danger of the dispersion of goods. A decision that protects not only the heir but also a large part of the Italian artistic heritage. The Torlonia collection is the result of several archaeological excavations the aristocratic family made on their own land, yet not only. Many works were “bought” from noble families in difficulty. Among the marbles there is the colossal head of Apollo of Kanachos, but also the Athlete of Myron, the relief of Portus with the representation of buildings, ships, protective gods and commercial life of the Ancient Port of Rome, the sarcophagus of Hector. In short, a collection experts considered even more important than that of the Capitoline and Vatican Museums. Prince Carlo Torlonia would rather not speak and simply comments as follows: “I would like these works of art to be part of a museum with my name, for example at Palazzo Giraud-Torlonia for all citizens of the world.
