And his lawyer, Adriana Boscagli, who made herself a name when it comes to multimillionaire hereditary divisions, explains that “the precautionary protection became necessary in consideration of some conduct of the co-heirs and the executor of the will that in our opinion could have definitively prejudiced the inheritance rights of my client”. In the appeal it is stated that Carlo Torlonia “only by chance” became aware, for example of the establishment of the Torlonia Foundation - in which neither he nor his children had any role – which had taken over the management of all the enormous collections of works of art on loan”. “This measure, explains Boscagli, tends to prevent both acts of dispersion of movable property such as statues, but also to prevent the completion of corporate transactions”. The spy on the “danger of expatriation of works of art” would have been lit up by a meeting in the United States between the current president of Banca del Fucino and representatives of the Paul Getty Museum, from what can be read in American court documents brought to the attention of the Italian judge. Was it to talk about the statues? And from the same papers we learn that 30 art experts were sent to Rome to evaluate the works, guests at Villa Albani in 2016. Circumstances that convinced the Italian judge to stop the succession waiting for greater clarity and then proceed to the division. (Translated and edited by Anna Martinelli)

title: Uber restarts from Turin. “We’ll give our app to taxis”
content:
Carles Lloret arrives by taxi at the La Stampa headquarters. Until a few months ago, it would have been just flat out unthinkable the very idea of the head of Uber for South-Western Europe using the services provided by those who, more than any other, have opposed the expansion of the company, with strikes and protests in every part of the world. “On the contrary, Uber Taxi will start right from Turin”, he announces. “For Turin’s automotive tradition, for its - neither too big nor too small – size, and for the number of taxi drivers who work there. The service will take off before Christmas and will allow to request a ride with a regular taxi from the Uber app, and in the near future there will be an option also on Google Maps. At the moment the American company in Italy offers only Black, which offers premium rides with a professional driver. “In almost ten years of activity we have gone from a single product to many: Uber is becoming a multi-modal transportation platform, which integrates all existing transport options, from public transport to bike sharing, up to hailing-services. Using taxi is part of this strategy and is already active in several cities around the world. 
“Uber Taxi will be a new starting point. We will offer taxi drivers an easy way to optimize their working hours, taking advantage of slow times to take up more rides, reducing pollution and wastage. We guarantee safety, transparency and flexibility, because drivers can decide to turn Uber on and off whenever they want”. 
“The dialogue of the deaf is over: we are talking to individual drivers, associations and institutions to try to understand how to offer a service that is an opportunity for everyone and could help to improve city mobility. It would be naive to believe that everything will work out fine this time, but we are looking at the long term. Our past experience has not been easy, now we want to operate exclusively in full compliance with the laws in force”. 
“We launched Uber Pop replicating the American model: in Italy, it didn’t work out and today it’s a closed chapter. The future of Uber cannot be separated from that of taxi drivers with a regular license. We hope that they will perceive our technology as a step forward and choose to use it: together we can build the future of transport, starting from Turin”. 
“They do a great job and they’ll be our competitors. Yet, more than competing with other apps, we aim to work together on the part of the service which is still offline and take it to smartphones. Thanks to Axa, we also provide drivers with additional insurance coverage, and not just for the rides booked with our app. In addition, we offer a very flexible collection system for drivers, which is not linked to weekly or monthly deadlines”. 
“As they wish: credit card or prepaid card, PayPal or cash. This last option was designed specifically for Italy, to respond to the requests of taxi drivers. However, cash payment for rides booked using the app will not be available at the time of the launch of the service, but will arrive later”.
“At the moment the service does not provide that option, when you call for a ride you book the entire car. Unless several people go from point A to point B together and decide on their own to divide the amount of the ride”. 
“If the price is variable, increasing the fares allows us to make it more profitable for drivers to work in a specific area or time slot: and in the end, more rides available means less traffic. But where prices are fixed, as in Italy, this strategy is not applied: the app will always give an estimate of the amount and the taximeter will be used. Uber will receive 7 per cent”.  “Well, many are surprised to be contacted by us, and we seem to grasp interest and curiosity. With the new CEO Dara Khosrowshahi we are changing our approach and working hard to earn the trust of our interlocutors, putting integrity at the center of every decision”. 
“Uber wants to be a reliable partner for Italian cities and cities around the world in the long run, working together on different transport alternatives, including taxis, to build smarter and cleaner urban environments. In Turin we never lacked the support of the institutions, but we can say the same for other Italian cities, where we will arrive soon after”.

title: 36th Torino Film Festival kicks off with Gary Hary biopic
content: “It’s ideas that matter in politics,” says Hugh Jackman in Jason Reitman’s The Front Runner, the film set to open the 36th Torino Film Festival tonight. The story of the rapid political decline of Democratic senator Gary Hart will cut the inaugural ribbon of the TFF, hosted for a third consecutive year by Emanuela Martini. The curtain rises with a commitment to public affairs and closes with the equally political Palme d’Or-winning director Nanni Moretti unveiling his latest film, Santiago, Italia as the closing night gala for the 36th Turin Film Festival on December 1. Moretti’s documentary is an examination of Italy’s role in Chile following the military coup that ended Salvador Allende’s democratically elected government on September 11, 1973. The festival is tinged with a Kierkegaardian feel–looking back as way to understand where we are going (even the official guide poster is dedicated to the red-haired Old Hollywood bombshell, Rita Hayworth)–which would please certain cinephiles in the age of Netflix who find solace and beauty watching in film in the pitch-black darkness of a room. The festival kicks off with The Front Runner screen and a party at the Mole Antonelliana (where the cinema of film is location in Turin), and runs until December 1st. During that week, there will be 133 features, 34 world premieres, 23 international films, and 59 Italian ones (of which three are also in world premiere in the Festa Mobile (Elisabetta Sgarbi, Bonifacio Angius and Daniele Segre)). From 4000 submissions, the admitted films are a delicate pastiche of genres and styles. The jury is headed by president Jia Zhang-ke (the explosive Chinese director who, on November 30th, will present his latest film The Children of the Yellow River at TFF and tonight will toast the opening of the festival together with his wonderful wife and muse, Zhao Tao (David di Donatello for I am Li)). The jury also includes guest director Pupi Avati, the Italian horror film producer known for his two masterpieces, The House with Laughing Windows (1976) and Zeder (1983); the English director Col Needham who created of the ImdB (Internet Movie Database) search engine; and colleagues Andreas Prochaska (Austria) and Miguel Gomes (Portugal).The only female Italian in the jury is the producer Marta Donzelli, who co-founded with Gregorio Paonessa Vivo Film, an independent production company with a portfolio of films that has won accolades from the most prestigious international festivals. “I’m tied to the TFF by an ancient relationship”, she explains. “Over the years the festival has hosted, and often rewarded many of our films. We also participated in the Torino Film Lab in its first year (ed. 2008) with The Four Times by Michelangelo Frammartino. The lab brought us a lot of good fortune, therefore I gladly accepted the idea of joining the jury.”Donzelli, who is part of the eponymous publishing house, says she is optimistic about the future of cinema. While it’s true that the ways in which people can be reached has changed–“instead of a single screen there are a thousand,” she said–“the experience of cinema in a theatre is unique and irreplaceable, and this message should be transmitted to the young, without getting into a discussion about the various content publishers.”She is now immersed in the post-production of Michela Occhipinti’s Flesh Out, Federico Bondi’s Dafne as well as in the preparation of Abel Ferrara’s Siberia and Chiara Malta’s Simple Women. Donzelli insists that cinema is a great source from which even fiction producers draw inspiration: “As directors we must be open to new ways of collaboration, and in this sense the festivals are very important because they’re an intersection of spectators, directors, screenwriters, and actors from which energy pulsates, and new frontiers open.”Donzelli adds, “I’m convinced that young people today must be told that the magic of cinema is a pleasure of life, and that it is not just a form of entertainment, but a cultural product and a luxury because having the courage to remain disconnected from the computer for two hours is an act of freedom.”As for the Turin Film Festival, she hopes to “see films capable of expanding horizons, introduce new creative landscapes, and discover new languages for images.” And on December 1, after having watched four films a day, hopefully be able to help choose the best film.

title: Di Maio gets interviewed for tv show Le Iene, admits father was wrong as three other claims of black workers emerge
content: The scandal involving Luigi Di Maio’s father, the entrepreneur Antonio, who allegedly employed a worker in his firm without a regular contract and was told to lie about a workplace accident, has only just begun to develop. More details are being brought to light as we speak: Yesterday a camera crew from television show, Le Iene, filmed the deputy prime minister at the Ministry of Labor. The first interview, which aired on Sunday evening, was nothing short of painful. Tonight you can see how it all plays in a second episode on Italia Uno, but chatter’s been growing in the meantime.According to close sources of the television crew, Di Maio admits in this second episode that his father had a employed a worker in black, the laborer Salvatore Pizzo, whose first complaint became public. As a sign of goodwill, the deputy prime minister provided the program a series of papers and documents that he managed to recover, trying to show maximum of cooperation on his part. Immediately after confirming that his father had made a mistake, he was asked if he was really sure that it was the only “mistake” in the family business. Reporters from Le Iene reportedly uncovered other cases of hiring illegal laborers—news that will certainly be hard to stomach for the deputy prime minister. One case involves someone who’d been working at the Antonio Di Maio company for eight months, also paid in black. At this point the vice premier supposedly promises other checks on the claims, just like in the first episode, when the interviewer tried to make sure that the second case was really the last. Nothing could be further from the truth as investigators allegedly uncover not two, but five cases of illegal employment in his father’s company. One of them claims to have worked in black for three years, while another person (a cleaning man at a local school and at the Di Maio company site) one day had to flee to the fields when an inspector arrived at the farm. Is it possible that the young Di Maio—who at that time had not yet owned a stake shares of the company, and had only done some bricklayer jobs (a sort of “university of life”, as they often say in the Five Star Movement, or apprenticeship)—never noticed anything, the interviewers ask? After all, he was 24 and 25 years old; hardly a child any longer. He purportedly replies that he learned a lot from the experience working as a bricklayer, and that these workers’ stories are but embellished.There are two questions hovering over this story: How far do the materials and the testimonies collected in this television report stretch? And in addition to tonight’s episode, are there more to come, if the claims made by these illegal workers were validated? Amid the heat on Sunday, the vice premier wrote the following Facebook post: “My father made mistakes in his life, and from this behavior I distance myself, but he is still my father. And you will also understand that it is unlikely that a father will tell his 24-year-old son something like that. “ But by chance there were also some irregularities in which the son, the young mason Luigi Di Maio, could have been a direct witness to?

title: My Brilliant Friend brought to life on HBO
content: “Girls, my house on Tuesday to watch My Brilliant Friend.” That’s what most messages said on Whatsapp between friends, colleagues, peers in the last few days. Texts by “girls” aged 25 to 65, all passionate readers of Elena Ferrante’s international bestselling quadrilogy, all united now by watching on TV together (since yesterday on Raiuno, but also in September when the cinemas were full of groups of women) after HBO airs the first novel of Ferrante’s four-part series by the Italian film director, Saverio Costanzo.My Brilliant Friend is an emotional experience before it is an artistic one–to mount the stage is the archetype and the mystery of female friendship, embodied by the relationship between Elena and Lila, the blonde and the brunette, the erudite and the brilliant, the shy and bold. A deep and complex bond that grows over the course of the novels just like in life, starting from childhood in the post-war Naples when the two girls (the talented Elisa Del Genio and Ludovica Nasti, while the teenagers are Margherita Mazzucco and Gaia Girace) meet in a poor and violent district. Dolls, school, work, love, marriage, divorce, children, struggles, books, suffering and passion, successes and failures. Set against a backdrop of sixty years of history and contradictions in Italy, the black market and the workers’ struggles, the economic boom and Gomorrah.A “hypnotic” story, at least according to Hillary Clinton. It’s no coincidence that the book has sold millions of copies in 40 countries and the series will be aired in 56 (the books are also wildly successful in America). On the other hand, friendship is truly a “splendid and dark” mystery, even more so for women who–despite illustrious testimonies of glorious, virile friendships that date back to the antiquity–were destined to end as wives and mothers. Yet who of us has not had a friend that was more beautiful or intelligent to emulate and envy in secret? One who you could argue with, who was both charming and treacherous? One who knows how to see through you and accept both the light and the darkness?Elena and Lila are two faces of the female mystery, they define each other through the eyes of the other, they love and challenge each other, only to discover in the end “that in the world there is nothing to win...and that time simply slipped away without any meaning, and it was good just to see each other every so often to hear the mad sound of the brain of one echo in the mad sound of the brain of the other.” And the best way to enjoy books and movies is to live them like a meeting of friends, ready to venture together towards the sea beyond the tunnel. “We took each other’s hands and went.” TRANSLATED BY

title: FCA to invest 5 billion, a new Fiat 500 electric model, plants in Italy towards full employment
content:
«Tomorrow morning. We are ready to kick off tomorrow morning». Pietro Gorlier, chief operating officer of the Emea region for FCA, repeated this statement several times during the meeting with journalists to explain that the 5 billion industrial plan in three years is already operational and will allow to achieve the goal of full employment in 2021. «Orders have already been placed». «A new Fiat 500 electric model will be produced at FCA’s historic Mirafiori plant in Turin, and the all-electric platform will be applied also on other vehicles at a global level», Mike Manley, CEO of Fiat Chrysler Automobiles explained in the meeting with the unions that signed the collective agreement of the group. 
From June 1st, when Sergio Marchionne presented his industrial plan the objectives have been refined - the focus is on electric and hybrid engines – choosing to invest on Italy in the next three years 5 of the 8.7 billion announced for the whole of Europe. Manley, in short, has decided to bet on Italy as union officials explained that «further investment in the brands Jeep, Alfa Romeo and Fiat will bring benefits from the use of existing production capacity, economies of scale and efficiencies on purchases resulting from the use of a common architecture». Then it was up to Gorlier to illustrate the details of a plan that provides for the launch of four new models and the review of another nine, while «twelve out of thirteen will have electrified or hybrid versions». A choice that also stems from the fact that the plan «has been calibrated to the current relatively stable market trend in both Italy and Europe, with a decline expected in 2020, for the entry into force of new regulations on “polluting” emissions». 
According to Gorlier, the first electric Fiat 500s will leave the Mirafiori plant at the beginning of 2020 and «the launch will be an emotional event. The Fiat 500 is a model that has survived through several generations, the fact that it is produced in Turin, in Mirafiori, has a significant value». Gorlier has not revealed the design of the new Fiat 500 but what is certain is that it will be hyper-technological. As mentioned, the investment is already operational and in the «next few months we will start training staff on electric and hybrid technologies». In Mirafiori and in the Grugliasco plant, the restyling will be carried out with installations of hybrid electric motors from Maserati Levante. The Ghibli and Quattroporte will also be redesigned. Another operational investment sees the arrival in the Melfi plant of the Jeep Compass production (so far only made in Mexico) in its plug-in hybrid electric version for the entire European market. Melfi will also make the renewed 500X and will develop its hybrid version, and work on the restyling of the Jeep Renegade with Phev and Hybrid engines. Investments in Pomigliano will also be immediately executive, where an Alfa Romeo Compact SUV, the Panda Hybrid, will be manufactured and the restyling of the Panda will be finalized. Cassino plant continues to work on the Alfa Romeo Giulietta, and gets the re-styling of the Giulia and Stelvio models, both in the electric version and of the Maserati D as well. In Modena, production of the Maserati Granturismo and Grancabrio continues, with two new super sports cars also in the electric version. 
In these months FCA has also decided not to renounce to diesel by 2021 as previously announced. This means that the Pratola Serra plant will develop the latest generation of euro6 diesel (D final) with low emission.

title: Ronaldo and Georgina buy all Christmas decorations of a shop window in Turin for charity
content: There was Santa Claus’ throne, and two illuminated white Christmas bushes sitting in the window of via Lagrange 5D. At least that’s where they were until three days ago, when Cristiano Ronaldo’s fiancée, Georgina Rodriguez, passed by and bought everything. Yesterday the ladies of Adisco had to redecorate their shop display again. On Tuesday, volunteers of the association went to the Ronaldo household to deliver the packages and brought teddy bears and reindeers, perfect to decorate their large windowsill overlooking the Mole. Georgina shared the pictures to her 8 million Instagram followers and revealed that her festive purchases will go in direction of charity. The caption read in Spanish: “How we enjoyed yesterday buying the Christmas decoration for our new home in Torino !!! We had a great time and we also felt the great satisfaction of knowing that we were contributing a good cause. We are happy to be able to collaborate with the ADISCO association that donates 100% of what it sells to the Regina Margherita Hospital.”It was a lengthy message and included a link to the website adiscopiemonte.it. In less than 24 hours, her post had gotten almost a million “Likes” on the platform, which for the non-profit organization could mean a shower of donations. It is the Ronaldo effect, a sweeping wave that for the first time engulfs a charity in Turin. It also marks a new chapter in CR7’s relationship between with city: the footballer’s family and his home, whose social media is used as a business, had never been exposed like this. Still, for the little ones at the Regina Margherita Hospital, the magic of Santa Claus is real.Georgina and her children has supposedly arranged the donation with the non-profit organization in secret, so her Instagram post turned out to be a nice surprise: “I just want to thank her or helping us and for sharing the news,” said President Maria Teresa Lavazza. The volunteers who met the Ronaldo described a united and happy family, who listened with interest to the association’s projects. Only a month ago the new Emergency Department of Regina Margherita was inaugurated, and the proceeds of this Christmas will hopefully finance the restyling of the Pediatric Oncohematology. “What a beautiful time, family togetherness, warmth, love, love. We must never forget those who REALLY need it,” Georgina concluded in her caption. The volunteers hope that next CR7 will pay a visit to the hospital to greet the children.

title: All the proposals for the new highway bridge in Genoa
content: The name of the company heading the reconstruction of the Morandi bridge in Genoa will be revealed on December 14, exactly four months after its tragic collapse. The seven men who screened the proposals will present their findings to Marco Bucci tomorrow morning, mayor and commissioner, who will make an executive decision. They’ve followed a timetable with hard deadlines to arrive at the decision on who will demolish and rebuild the viaduct. “If all goes well, we could sign the contract on the 14th,” says Bucci. Fifteen projects were submitted by companies that proposed to demolish, rebuild, or do both. A clear favorite is the proposal by shipbuilder Fincantieri and the Salini Impregilo team who are supported by Italferr, an engineering company of the Fs group. Their project is estimated to take a longer time than initially foreseen, but overall is rather similar in structure (classic beam bridge, inspired by Renzo Piano’s design) for the original proposal. If approved, their project would take 12 months without demolition, against the nine of Aspi that would including demolition, both costing just over 200 million. Cimolai is a strong runner up, given its flexibility—four different solutions—and aesthetically appealing use of Calatrava designer structures.Even if Bucci is decides to go with a proposal that sees quicker completion, his eagerness may be pushed back by more cautionary agents who are looking for a ‘demolition’ plan that first and foremost prioritizes preservation (for this reason it is necessary to wait for the results on the remains of the viaduct being analyzed in Switzerland, and which will not be in Genoa before December 17). In order to proceed with the demolition it is necessary to receive approval from the prosecution—chief prosecutor Francesco Cozzi has already spoken with Bucci and reiterates the guidelines: “We agree with the mayor that as soon as the demolition plan is ready we will analyze it. We will not put signatures without having analyzed everything in detail.”The Proposals FINCANTIERIA viaduct in honor of Renzo Piano’s designThe proposal of the consortium Salini Impregilo-Fincantieri is a favorite for reconstruction (also because it is blessed by the MS5 in government). The project includes a classic viaduct, inspired by architect Renzo Piano’s original design. It will cost slightly over 200 million euros, and will take 12 months to construct (without demolition). The design is supported another state company, Italferr, the engineering company of the Ferrovie dello Stato group.CIMOLAICimolai submitted four proposals, each more complex, costly, and aesthetically pleasing, all signed by the architect Santiago Calatrava. The construction times range between 11 and 19 months, with startings costs at 200 million euros. The two most demanding solutions provide a cable-stayed bridge and an arched one. The latter (pictured) would be called Porta Mediterranea II. PIZZAROTTI The Emilia-Romagna based company Pizzarotti proposed two solutions: one with a new viaduct in the exact space occupied by the old Morandi, with the same sequence of stays and the construction of an arch-frame (the carriageway is straight from the bottom) instead of cable-stayed towers. The other solution differs in with the idea of demolishing and rebuilding at the same time. In this case the carriageways would overlap and would not be placed side by side. It would take 12 months, with an estimated cost of 200 million.ITALIANA COSTRUZIONIThe Rome-based company Italiana Costruzioni has proposed a environmentally-friendly reconstruction of the bridge almost in entirely in steel. The new viaduct, with a classic line, has large diagonal struts to support the deck from below, in a sort of overturned Morandi. One of the stays of the old bridge will be preserved to make a memorial. Among the special features, photovoltaic systems and a mini wind turbine. It would cost less than 250 million.CCCC-SALCThe Chinese giant CCCC and Italian Salc also proposed more than one solution. The quickest would one would allow vehicular traffic to reopen to within 11 months. Among the ideas is also a cable-stayed version, which includes two large towers and support cables to overcome the railway and the Polcevera torrent.RICCIARDELLOThe Ricciardello company from Messina has proposed a conservative solution, which would make it possible to recover the western section of the Morandi. The east one would instead be supplanted by three V-shaped cable stay towers. The strengths of the proposal are the times and costs—just over nine months and 122 million euros, including a large park dedicated to the victims of the collapse that has upset the city.

title: Donatella Versace, Made in Italy is the way: we will continue to produce here, fashion creates jobs”
content: “Fashion could be a magnet for young people looking for a future in Italy. Versace will create many new jobs, we produce everything here, including T-shirts. The Made in Italy label is a very important value that gives enormous growth prospects. We will open two companies for accessories, such as shoes and bags, and about one hundred shops in a year and a half". Donatella Versace, proud and satisfied of the great step she took in selling  Versace to the Michael Kors group, which from January 1st will be called Capri Holdings, a new luxury hub that will includes both the brands Michael Kors and Jimmy Choo. We meet her two months after the sale - to quiz what has changed and will change - in the Milan offices of the brand in Via Borgospesso, while works are in full swing at the new headquarters in Viale della Liberazione opposite the Diamond Tower. There, The Corner will tower over the city  (this mega-building will also host the Inter football team). “The change is radical. Versace is a great iconic brand with a unique history, known throughout the world. But to remain this way even when I’m gone, it needed investment. Today, large family-owned companies do not count as they once did because the world has changed, there is technology, there are large groups such as LVMH and Kering. In the last two years things were going well, I didn’t really think about revolutionizing everything, then I was approached by various people from these groups, until John Idol (CEO of Capri Holdings) arrived. “He told me: “I want to make a luxury group but I don’t have luxury companies, you with Versace would be our prestigious brand, I’m not interested in anyone else, do you agree?”. And when he came to visit the archive, he was enraptured by the clothes designed for Jennifer Lopez, Lady D... In the end, he had tears in his eyes. We happened to be on the same wavelength since the beginning". “At first it was bad because too many rumors were spreading. So, with Idol we organized a huge meeting at the Odeon Cinema, even with those who work in the factory in Novara. And we thoroughly explained that everything would change for the better: more investments in marketing, in technology with a digital platform designed by Bill Gates, more factories. Especially for bags and shoes. Because we are among the few to make the bulk of our turnover only on clothes, and now we want to expand on accessories which- until yesterday - were produced by external laboratories. During this meeting, we also had the opportunity to clarify many other aspects to our employees”.“Newspapers wrote that Michael Kors had bought us, but Kors, whom I admire so much, has nothing to do with it, as it is one of the three companies in the group. The group is not American, even though it is listed on Wall Street. Capri Holdings has its headquarters in London and is based in British Virgin Island. Our internal CEO remains the English Jonathan Akeroyd. He is like a boss – of Versace, Jimmy Choo and Michael Kors -... But so am I, because with my daughter Allegra and my brother Santo, I reinvested in  Holdings, we are among the top six investors”. “Well, actually, the condition was that I stayed. I’ll stay here, I’m tied hands and feet here. Holdings absolutely wants our Italian know-how. I’m studying, doing my researches. As well as being the artistic director of Versace, I will also oversee the strategies with Idol, because this part too must be followed with a creative eye”. “Yes, the one in Miami, for example, is white on the outside with the black Medusa, but inside it is made of interchangeable elements. Everybody likes more or less the same things but in a different way and the boutiques must be eclectic, giving the possibility to diversify. Every city has its own needs: Milan is not Miami. In the store in Florence, for example, there is an antique piece, to underline the peculiarity of that city. We have just inaugurated Monaco and Beijing will follow with other features. Then others will open”. “I’ve wanted to do this for a long time. I chose Gianni’s birthday, which is a good omen, and I chose New York because I love working with Americans and I love this city, where I had a home with my brother for 15 years. The défilé is an investment in the brand. The theme is a must for the brand: the return of safety pins. I started from the past to turn it into the present. Do you remember the dress of Elizabeth Hurley, next to Hugh Grant, studded with safety pins? It was that dress that launched her. It went around the world. Obviously it won’t be the same". “Yes, I couldn’t talk about him because he died in such a brutal way. If it had been an illness, I would have come to terms with it. But now I’m happy to remember his playful side, the complicity of our relationship. I think he’d be happy to see me recall the things we had fun doing together". “I have two closets. One with everything I use now. The other with my beloved clothes that I would never wear again, but I like to touch them to relive certain emotions. My favorite is a dress that Gianni had made for me in black leather and rhinestones, a sort of sleeveless chemisier, with a white collar. It’s so beautiful, I could lose my mind. I wore it on at the opening of Avedon’s photographic show, in the States, many years ago. I’m not tied to the past, I prefer to talk about how I dress today. With softer clothes. I love my men’s gold watch with its wide bracelet, the black T-shirts – I have about thirty all alike - and short skirts with  leggings, like this tartan mini kilt I’m wearing now”. “Those always! I recommend all ladies the ankle boots with laces, a bit higher on the ankles to hide the parts that are not perfect. They have a 12-cm heel, but with the wedge in front they become 6 cm and are very comfy”. “I wear a black stretch tank top and jogging pants from our sports line, with a gold meander at the waist. And I walk barefoot, I only use sneakers at the gym”. “No, never, I don’t care, my passion is writing. I don’t take notes on my mobile phone, I write on a booklet where I put down how I would like the models to look: narrow shoulder, high waist, dry silhouette... then I call the guys who draw and I explain them the color combinations. Maybe it’s a legacy of my classical education (she studied at the faculty of humanities in Florence, ed.). In high school, I used to write essays for everyone, while I hated numbers, so the others passed me their math homework. Then I read a lot, all the newspapers in the morning on my iPad. And many books. The last one is Becoming by Michelle Obama. She gave it to me herself”. “I’m interested in young people and those who have clear ideas and something to say. Some of my followers impress me and I want to get in touch with them. You need to get out of the circle of people who protect you and meet the other to understand what’s going on". “Yes, very much. In the 90s, I was a friend of Prince and Madonna, now I like hip hop, the lyrics make me think, they are socially engaged, reading them I get to understand other cultures. My favorites are The Migos (the ones from the song Versace Versace Versace), Grace and Nicki Minaj. Artists who are fearless. Minaj does not have a perfect body: a prosperous breast, toned legs, but she is magnificent. It shows that to feel beautiful you don’t have to be thin, tall and starve to death". “Yes, I love Michelle Obama, but all women are strong. But some women need to make themselves understood. Women in Italy have great unexpressed strength, they must make themselves heard". “People are fleeting because what the government is doing does not help our beautiful country, politicians are ruining it. Ignorance cannot be commented on. “I don’t see myself, I love the present which I need to build the future”.

title: Italian dictionary expands with 3,505 new words
content:
From economics to politics to religion, thousands of new words have been added to the Italian dictionary. In fact, one of Italy’s most active producers of neologisms is Pope Bergoglio, who has created words like “balconare”, “mafiarsi”, “nostalgiare”, and “nonbastisti” (translated in current Italian means along the lines to not say that whatever we do is not enough). Linguistically speaking, we highly creative people and our and skills are growing, at least according to Giovanni Adamo and Valeria Della Valle, scientific directors of the Neologismi volume. The recently published book is a compilation of new words from newspapers between 2008-2018, edited by the Institute of the Italian Encyclopaedia.
The two analysts have screened 3,505 new entries. The information comes from reviewing 76 newspapers and represents a set of unregistered but commonplace. What are the sectors most affected by this growth? The most malleable industry would be the economy, incorporating the use of new words like “spreaddometro” (speedometer), “agenzia di rating” (rating agency), “criptovaluta” (cryptocurrency), and even “finanzcapitalismo” (financial capitalism) (a mega-machine created to maximize the value of human beings and ecosystems).
Information technology is another section booming with neologisms. From from cloudcomputing (the technology that allows the use of remote software and hardware resources) to “datacrazia” (datocracy) (systems of governance that manifest through data collection). The realm of science has also welcomed once-unfamiliar expressions, like no-vax or generic product, and so has politics, with a flurry of new terms like “cangurare” (the practice that allows you to group similar amendments to make them cancel or approve en bloc) to “casaleggismo” (denoting a party affiliation to the Five Star Movement and Gianroberto Casaleggio, editor of the Beppe Grillo’s blog), ‘criccopoli’, ‘doppiofornismo’, Eurotechnocrat, and so on.
Who is responsible for all this creative new jargon? Many linguists have said that the writer and poet Guido Ceronetti for one is responsible for words like “eterofono” (to speak different languages from those normally used in a country), “ginecida” (or gendercide; the systematic killing of members of a specific gender, especially women), “guerrasantista” (the holy war). In the entertainment industry we have the singer Mina, who is responsible for the word “fantagossip” (or false, useless rumors); Adriano Celentano (who invented “pronuclearide” for those who support the nuclear energy) and Enrico Vanzina, who came up with explosive words such as “amicismo”.As for politics, Francesco Rutelli leads the way with words like “élitometro” (elite rating system), “flippismo” (to make flippant decisions), and “polveronismo” (to confuse or mislead; murkiness). From “chiunquismo” to “zerbinismo”, journalists in the field responsible for new wordsBeat reporters–political, cultural, scientific, economic–have an intricate understanding of language. So much so that they (can) invent new words on a daily basis and inject them in our vocabulary. From “chiunquismo” (the attitude of those who believe that anyone can do any kind of activity) to “permalism”, “libridine”, “telepopolo”,  “bocconismo”, “lodenvestito”, “maggiordomocrazia” and “zerbinismo” (being a doormat). But does a whimsical lexicon indicate a positive expansion of Italian culture? “The number of words is growing but there is an overarching laziness” says Della Valle. “Journalists, who should filter information, use foreign words directly or literally follow non-Italian phrases. They don’t teach anything. And then today’s new words often have limits. For example, we use many anti-prefixes. The “non” precedes the great: non-state, non-growth, non-truth and so on. While these new terms are the product of strong creativity, they are also of dispute.”

title: Journey to Piaggio, the factory producing the first all-electric Vespa scooter
content:
Riding the first all-electric Vespa scooter is like floating through air. Dubbed the Vespa Elettrica, it has no engine and doesn’t require any oil or fuel to take off. It’s unbelievably quiet, with close to no vibrations. The lithium battery is designed to last 100 km and takes about four hours to fully charge from a standard wall outlet. The instruction manual is replete with words and descriptions referencing the vague and ever-changing world we live in: interconnectivity, rechargeable, ‘power’, ‘reverse gear’, and recuperating kinetic energy. Unlike its 1973 predecessor–the Vespa 50 Special, praised by the musician Cesare Cremonini–the new, electric model is a direct response to the demands of an increasingly globalized and ecologically-minded world. 
From a structural point of view, the Elettrica is a derivative of the Primavera model. Understandably so that despite the changes, the soul must remain the same as that first sample from April 1946, and all the 18 million models sold since then throughout the world.The scooter is produced in a factory Piaggio in Pontedera–the same factory where Enrico Piaggio and Corradino D’Ascani produced the first model–and the first stages of processing are the same as that of traditional models: body parts are assembled (or welded on) through a system of automated arms (480 ‘stitches’, precise up to the deci millimeter, according to the technicians), the skeleton is then passed through a scanner and sent to painting for a first top and base coat (black and coral respectively). It is at this point that the new Vespa separates itself from its predecessors. While the others continue a journey where they may end up in any of 26 different colors, the Elettrica will only be painted in a specific shade of gray–neither light nor dark, but “chrome”.
There are six assembly lines in the Pontedera plant. The third one is reserved for the Electtrica. The gray shell, or rather “chrome”, rises empty on the platform and after about twenty transitions turns into the first zero emissions scooter of the house. Forget cylinder and piston, oil and gasoline, because the eco-technology is made of tens of meters of cables, transformers, microchips, and circuits, and a power unit that governs everything: the battery pack block weighs about 25 kilograms and is placed under the compartment of the saddle. Not too cumbersome, since you save both the space for a jet helmet and, above all, the unmistakable Vespa profile. Combining design and technology seems obvious, and yet the Piaggio engineers who have worked there day and night for months ensure that it is a small miracle.On the road, the first surprise is the registration plate–the same as a 50. Although the price of an Elettrica is not exactly for teenagers (6.390 euros), with a steady power of 3.5 kW and a peak power of 4 kW, it can be driven from the age of 14. But the real game changer happens at the time of ignition. Turn the key in the switchgear, hold down a button under the throttle grip for three seconds (unlike the other scooters there is no need to press the brake lever at the same time) and...nothing. No smell of gas, not even a bit of smoke, but above all, no noise. It seems to have ended up in a silent film. Before hitting the road, you only need to select the driving mode. There are two: power or echo. The second guarantees a battery life of about 100 km as declared by Piaggio (but limits the Vespa to 30 km/h); the first gives the scooter a bit more oomph, reaching speeds up to 45 km/h (which is roughly the same as a 50cc scooter), but will burn the battery life at a 20% faster rate.
In a test drive on the Piaggio track in Pontedera, the acceleration is typical of electric motors–the torque of 200 Nm at the wheel ensures brilliant performance, something that the Vespa 50 engine can only dream of. The weight of the battery is heard, but does not affect the stability or braking. On the other hand, the addition of riding in reverse makes parking easier. There’s also a 4.3-inch TFT color display in between the handlebars, and a Bluetooth connection system that can promptly display messages or phone calls. As for the recharge? In the nozzle where once fuel was put in, there is now a cable that connects to any standard wall outlet and takes about four hours for a full recharge.

title: Anti-Semitic outrage: 20 stumbling stones stolen in Rome
content: The 20 Stolpersteine were stolen in the night between December 9 and 10, in Rome, in the Monti district. Dedicated to the victims of the Shoah, and created by the German artist Gunter Demnig, the Holocaust memorial stones installed in 2012 in Via Madonna dei Monti 82 were devoted to members of the Di Castro and Di Consiglio families, swept away by the Nazi-fascist deportations and the massacre of the Fosse Ardeatine.Giulia Spizzichino, of the Di Consiglio family and whose testimony was fundamental for the trial of the Nazi criminal Erich Priebke, died two years ago. “I feel as if they have put salt on an open wound” - Lidia Spizzichino, Giulia’s sister tells La Stampa, - When they deported my family I was 12 years old, and today I feel exactly as I did then. Of course, you don’t need memorial stones to remember, but this grave gesture confirms that anti-Semitism is still an evil to be fought in our country. Our memory - that of all of us - has been offended again”. “It is the worrying sign of a new barbarity”, The President of the Senate Elisabetta Alberti Casellati said in a message addressed to the Jewish community - a wicked act against the testimony and memory of the ferocity endured by the Jewish people and the Roman community”.Senator Liliana Segre, who in Milan is chairwoman of the committee that deals with the Stolpersteine, also spoke on the matter: “I find that stealing the commemorative plaques that have no tomb is something so horribly coward that I have no words”.The President of the Jewish community Ruth Dureghello, the Mayor Virginia Raggi, the President of the Chamber, and the President of the Lazio Region have all taken to twitter to condemn the act. Meanwhile, Public Prosecutor’s Office has opened a file for theft aggravated by racial hatred, and last night was held a rally in the Monti area which was attended by residents of the neighborhood.()

title: Discovering Ranthambore, Bengal tigers’ last reserve
content:
Intensive cultivation and shortage of prey have reduced the tigers’ habitat by ninety-five percent.We leave at dawn, hoping to be the only ones, yet in a short time we find ourselves amid dozens of other convertible jeeps and trucks flooding the streets of this small Indian town build half a meter above a creek of lurid water that flows under the squared huts. On the badly paved road we see wild- boars, dromedaries elephants, dogs, goats and cows waking up while people go about their daily bargains. A troop of highly motivated tourists lashes out honking their way through town. A half an hour after our departure, it seems that the entire tourist flow of Rajasthan, and a good part of Indians from all over the sub-continent, have gathered up in Ranthambore with the only purpose to see the tiger.The Ranthambore park, established in 1955, was actually the hunting reserve of the maharaja who came here to track down precisely the tiger. In every hotel or resort there are black and white photos of those carnages, showing tigers trampled underfoot and dominated in curious unreal positions. Today the total surface of the reserve reaches 1300 square kilometers, which is no small area, if you consider that the region is inhabited and intensively cultivated up until the stone-wall that marks the border: Jaipur is only 100 km away. They say that Ranthambore is the best places to see tigers in their natural habitat (the reserve counts about 50), yet it is difficult to believe it, for all the traffic, the confusion and the noise that precedes them. But instead, as soon as we enter, the first thing we see are the tigers’ gigantic footprints standing out on the sand. However, for most visitors, this will probably be the most they will be able to see of the big feline, now in danger of extinction. The three-hour long safaris don’t guarantee you will get to see a Bengali tiger. 
Since the beginning of the 20th century, the population and distribution area of the tigers have been reduced by 95%, due to rampant poaching, shortage of prey, intensive cultivation and habitat destruction. In 2010, the world’s population reached an all-time low of about 3200 (now 3890), prompting 13 governments to launch, with WWF, the “TX2”, a project that aims to double the number of free-range big cats by 2022.In the main areas of Asia, the number of specimens could be increased from 165 to 585, provided, however, that effective action is taken in anti-poaching activities and in the maintenance of prey, necessary for the survival of these large carnivores. This requires strong political will, a responsive governance, investment and public support, but the condition for increasing the tiger population is the growth of prey - or at least to maintain its current status number, while systems to reduce the risk of conflict between humans and wildlife are essential to ensure safe coexistence between wild tiger populations and local communities. It is, on another scale, the same controversial issue that is currently recorded in Italy for wolves: apparently, they are symbols of great value for all, but they must not create problems. That is, in real terms, they must stop being what they are and become pets.
Yet this is not only about an obvious ecological advantage, increasing the number of tigers would also bring economic ones, if one considers that in Ranthambore alone there are thousands of workers who benefit from tourists paying to spot a tiger. And that a safari costs 90 euros or more.Today, the building of a new road threatens the remaining tranquility of the park and the pressure of the homo sapiens is growing, but if there is a place where these magnificent animals can resist is India, where the traditional respect for every creature’s soul includes also that of these stunning felines. The tiger was a fierce enemy both for Kipling and the Maharajas, yet not for the Indian people, even despite the problems and tragedies of the past: Shere-Khan was not entirely wrong in trying to stop Mowgli from becoming a man.Meanwhile, near a waterway, the truck abruptly stops along with the others: in the foggy backlight of the morning, when all hopes were lost, a tiger’s head appears in a distant silhouette, while the rest of the body remains completely under water.In the absolute silence that suddenly dropped, the tiger slowly turns its huge head to look at us distracted and, at the end of its “bath” (tigers love water, contrary to what is believed), it gets up, shake itself off, and lazily moves away crossing the road and passing right close to the jeeps. A magnificent male individual, of about 300 kg: he is calm, relaxed and not at all bothered, while about fifty people are left stunned. We are just a few steps away from the cultivated fields. Stuck in that jam, I spent the ten most exciting minutes of my life. Coexistence is possible, what could possibly go wrong?

title: The new rights challenge
content: The 70th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights represents an arrival and a departure: it is a moment to look back at how the protection of individuals marked the advance of democracies after the atrocities of World War II and a moment to look ahead and understand how that challenge today must be renewed to protect new forms of rights.In “Rights from Wrongs” Harvard law academic Alan Dershowitz writes that in the history of humanity great rights come from great mistakes, to prevent them from happening again. That same reaction happened on December 10, 1948, when the Universal Declaration introduced a new way to protect individuals from the “crimes against humanity” committed by totalitarian regimes in unprecedented horrific ways.The Declaration was not enough to prevent massacres and mass killings but created a higher and more powerful standard for the protection of human rights that cannot be ignored. We are now facing the challenge to introduce similar standards to protect new rights and extend the protection of individuals to situations unimaginable in the last century.It has become a pressing challenge especially for two reasons: economic inequalities and digital reality.Addressing inequalities means protecting new rights affecting the economy because the welfare system resulting from the industrial revolution is no longer enough to resolve the profound transformation of our society. If at the end of the 19th century, the opening of factories and the use of electricity brought the need to protect factory workers and laid the foundations of a welfare state aimed at protecting families – with solutions changing state by state – the globalization and the development of new technologies are today calling for new forms of social protection. We need to train those who lost their job as a result of new technologies, respond to the distress of those who don’t earn enough but are not poor, improve the education of individuals to help them compete with robots, and protect elderly citizens as average life expectancy is projected to reach 100 years by imposing longer-term and more sophisticated welfare solutions.Finally, the challenge is about redefining the economic and social rights of individuals and adapt them to the needs of the 21st century.A similar situation can be found in the field of digital reality, where human activities have transferred to a dimension that in the last century did not exist. The arrival of the Internet, online communications, virtual reality and artificial intelligence, prompted the transfer to the web of most human activities, creating the need to extend to this reality the protection of individual rights that safeguard individuals in their daily life.It’s an epic challenge that originates from the protection of privacy, personal identity, and intellectual rights and extends to uncharted territories such as the digital transaction of goods and services without going through laws, national borders and international treaties. It’s about elaborating, defining and protect all the protagonists of such transactions. Addressing new socio-economic and digital rights is urgent as their absence, not only as legislation but also theoretically, is prompting a growing number of people in advanced democracies to forms of collective protest and personal aggression that pose a threat to the basic rules of coexistence. Hence the urgency, not only for academics and lawmakers but also for each one of us, to dedicate more time to studying the current social transformations and contribute to elaborate enough responses to update the body of individual rights.

title: Rome blanketed in smoke after huge fire breaks out at disposal plant
content:
A large fire broke out on Tuesday at a waste treatment plant on the northern outskirts of Rome, sending thick, black smoke into the sky above the capital. Mayor Virginia Raggi appealed to local authorities in Lazio and other regions to lend a hand and open up their depots to treat Rome’s trash for the foreseeable future. People near the site were told to keep windows shut and stay indoors.City hall said it had called the national civil protection agency and the environmental protection agency to an emergency task force meeting for concerns with air quality in the area. The environment minister, Sergio Costa, warned back in January that Italy could be sanctioned by the EU unless authorities in Rome and the Lazio region tackle the waste disposal crisis.
The biggest fear is that the plan will not be sufficient to overcome the critical issues. Ama, the firm in charge of collecting the city’s waste, has long been accused for years of failing to stop piles of rubbish mounting up on the streets. And then, in the face of betrayed promises, the Five Star Movement would have to pay a higher price in terms of consent. The first cause of doubt comes from protestors shouting “Shame on you” upon the mayor and minister Costa upon their arrival at the fire site for failing to close the plant (despite being one of Raggi’s guarantees in her electoral campaign). The mayor ensures that by the end of her term the TMB Salario plant will be closed for good, but forgets the all-important “if” at the back of everyone’s mind at the Capitol: “If the waste collection, which is currently around 50 percent, doesn’t reach 70 percent by 2021, we will not be able to close that plant.” This uncertainty makes Ama workers nervous too. The Salaria plant has been the subject of protests for years by residents complaining of putrid smells and demanding its closure, while workers at the plant have been condemning work and safety conditions at the facilities.
Raggi’s main concern at the moment is overcoming Christmas, when waste collection in Rome will increase from 4500 to 8000 tons a day. The plan agreed upon between the municipality, Ama, and the Lazio region, will see the waste treatment plant in Ostia be turned on (despite MS5 wanting to keep it inactive) to treat an additional 150 tons of waste a day. Breathing room? Not so much, as Rome will have to fork up millions of euros to transfer the waste to other municipalities and regions, like Aprilia, Viterbo, and Frosinone. Then there are the two landfills in Malagrotta, and the agreement with Abruzzo pending renewal; Abruzzo already treats 70,000 tons of waste annually and Raggi is now asking for them to increase their capacity. The problem, this time, is that the damage to the plant is huge and the emergency situation is expected to last for months, if not years. 
Arson was suspected as the blaze put the plant out of operation indefinitely. From senate vice president Paola Taverna, to Di Maio, who vehemently denied the conspiracy (but later added that “Raggi has tried to undermine a series of powers who didn’t take it very well”). Meanwhile, the chairman of the Ecomafie commission, M5S’ Stefano Vignaroli, says he prefers to wait for the investigations of the judiciary to determine the cause. Then, as soon as the Ecomafie commission is fully operational, Vignaroli promises to “start a survey on fires in waste disposal plants, too frequent throughout Italy. One every eight days.”

title: With the ecotax, FCA will rethink investments in Italy
content: FCA comes out into the open against the ecotax on diesel and petrol cars. For the first time since the introduction of the bonus-malus measure, yesterday Fiat Chrysler Automobiles decided to “take their foot off the brake”: if the measure is not modified to avoid the penalties, the group will be forced to review its 5 billion euros investment plan in Italy. An ambitious agenda that provides for the launch of 13 new models or the restyling of existing ones and new engines with the use of hybrid and electric technologies.Lingotto has reached this decision yesterday morning after a meeting convened Tuesday in Rome by the Ministry of Development whose results were deemed disappointing. Minister Di Maio’s intentions to intervene on the ecotax were not enough to reassure not only FCA but the entire automotive world. So much so that yesterday the 3 major associations of manufacturers (Anfia, Unrae and Federauto) also spoke up, reiterating their firm opposition to the proposal and pointing their finger at the damage that the tax would create on the job front. The measure, the associations warn, “would translate into a serious destabilizing factor for the sector, putting employment at risk”.But the first to launch the stone yesterday morning was Pietro Gorlier, FCA Head of the Emea area (Europe, Middle East and Africa), with a letter addressed to the President of the Regional Council of Piedmont. “In the last days – Gorlier writes - the scenario has been modified by interventions on the car market in discussion within the Budget Law, which in our opinion alter the entire framework of action within which the plan for Italy had been outlined. If such intervention were confirmed, starting from 2019, it will be necessary a deepened examination of the impact of the maneuver and a relative updating of the plan”.The possible freezing of the investment plan triggered reactions from both the world of politics and unions. “If the plan presented to the unions is solid, FCA ought to continue the confrontation with the government,” replied the Mayor of Turin Chiara Appendino, while for the President of the Piedmont Region, Sergio Chiamparino “worries about this lack of certainty of government policies in such a strategic sector for Piedmont and Italy”. At the Mirafiori plant in Turin, the plan included major investments in the production of the Fiat 500 electric and the renewal of the Maserati Levante, Quattroporte and Ghibli models, as well as the objective of progressively achieving full employment.On the union front, Cisl leader, Annamaria Furlan, invited the government to avoid “the risk of FCA rethinking the plan”. “Unfortunately, our biggest fears are coming true”, notes another Union top official, Rocco Palombella. “We will find ourselves in the grotesque situation of Di Maio - by decree - cancelling jobs of his fellow workers in Pomigliano,”. Michele De Palma, Fiom’s car manager, also said that “FCA’s plan must be implemented and not called into question”. After the load of controversial reactions, in the evening, deputy-premier Di Maio tried to reassure the sector: “We will find a solution without damaging or causing shock to the industrial plans of the companies”. But the automotive industry, as Uil Union’s General Secretary points out, is now on the alert: “We will not allow a 200,000-employees sector to be called into question due to sloppiness”.

title: Europeans, let’s take back control of our future
content:
What do Philip Stark, Costa-Gravas, Ian McEwan, Ottavia Piccolo, Wim Wenders, Fernando Savater and Robert Menasse have in common? They are among the dozens of signatories of the Manifesto for Europe with which the Association Civico has launched a call to arms for a Union that represents a collective project truly close to its citizens. It is a way of empowering European women and men to regain their dream of a continent of growth, peaceful and connected, while respecting different identities. It’s the starting point for a major mobilization which will culminate on March 22 at the European Parliament in Brussels. 15 European newspapers, including La Stampa, are taking part in its launch. The manifesto’s signatories include Mercedes Bresso, Francesca Ratti, Francesco Profumo, Daniel Cohn-Bendit, Ferdinando Nelli Feroci, Elmer Brok, Guy Verhofstadt and Sandro Gozi. 
As commemorations of the First World War Centenary come to an end, the CIVICO Europa movement, together with the civic tech Make.org and many well-known Europeans, is launching a non-partisan civilian campaign in the 28 member states of the European Union to mobilise citizens and empower them to take back control of the European project: #WeEuropeans.On 22nd March 2019, a Congress of Europeans will take place in the European Parliament, home of the Union’s citizens.Citizens from all walks of life, including artists and people who work in education, culture, science, business, labour and the media, will meet in this transnational forum to share a civic agenda resulting from the biggest public European consultation ever undertaken.This agenda, to be adopted in the presence of representatives of different political families who are there to listen to their constituents, will then be disseminated through a vast mobilisation campaign in all countries of the European Union. It will be submitted to all candidates in the European elections and to the Heads of State and Government at the European Council meeting in Sibiu on 9th May on the future of the Union. We will invite political leaders to react to our fellow citizens’ common worries and to decide whether or not to integrate them into their election campaigns. For us, this method constitutes the only very broad participatory approach capable of opening the way to a democratic revival of the European project, which we believe is the most important democratic project of our time.Never have the Union’s citizens’ levels of expectation about Europe been so high since the beginning of the crises. Citizens want a Union that responds to their needs and has a concrete and positive impact in their daily lives. More than ever, they believe European solutions are needed to respond to the great challenges of our time that none of our countries can address on its own. We want a Europe that protects us and defends our values and our interests in the world. A Europe that takes the lead in the fight against climate change and the battle for sustainable development, and that encourages digital innovation in the service of its citizens. A Europe that develops a common and dignified migration policy that guarantees the security of our borders. A Europe that promotes peace, democracy, social justice and economic prosperity. Today, however, while citizens desire more unity and efficacy, they doubt the capacity and political courage of European states to continue progressing together and to create the conditions for a positive future for all. They feel they no longer have control of their future, and are being written out of their own history in a deeply changing and worrisome world.Everywhere, crises are generating inward-looking responses and a search for scapegoats. Solidarity among States, the historical foundation of our Union, is being sorely tested. Precisely when we most need to work together, a mistrust of European institutions is taking hold. This doubt is amplified by the silence of political leaders, their lack of shared vision, the fake news on social networks and the omnipresence of extremist forces in the media, often supported by foreign activists, who set citizens against peoples.In this context, the European parliamentary elections of May 2019 will be very different from previous ones: They oblige us to recognize the uncompromising truth and to achieve an unprecedented democratic leap. We must regain our self-confidence and give soul to our Union that too often is reduced to a technocracy imprisoned by the intergovernmental method.We, citizens of the Union, of all opinions and origins, we Europeans, believe it is first of all we who are Europe and we who make Europe – and that people must be reminded of this fact.This is why we call all European citizens to join us in writing together a new positive and democratic page in our common history, and to pressure our representatives to assume their responsibilities and give themselves the means to bring real solutions to the challenges we face.May all who wish to join us do so without delay at WeEuropeans.eu and #WeEuropeans. The civic momentum we seek to build supersedes partisan divides and national silos. We need each of you to support our common cause. Europeans, let us together take back control of our future!

title: Gender Gap, despite minimal progress, Italy still amid the worst in the world
content: According to the World Economic Forum’s new report, Italy rose from 82nd to 70th place out of 149 countries. Still too few women in politics and at the top of companies.Which are the countries where being born with two X chromosomes instead of one X and one Y is enough to drastically reduce your chances of studying, getting the right salary, participating in politics and being able to count on fair health care? the World Economic Forum answers to these questions in its latest report on the Global Gender Gap. In the global ranking, Italy is 70th, last year it was 82nd.At the bottom of the 149 countries - analyzed according to the indicators found by the UN agencies and the European Commission - are Yemen, Pakistan, Iraq and Syria. On top Iceland, Norway, Sweden and Finland. It is a snapshot of the gender gap in four key areas: Economy, Politics, Health and Education.It doesn’t matter whether the health conditions are better or worse, what counts in this ranking is how big the differences between men and women are, and whether this gap has improved or worsened. That’s why Italy ranks lowest in Western European - worse than us is only Greece, Malta and Cyprus – while in the world ranking Nicaragua and Namibia, Costa Rica and Honduras do better.Italy’s small leap forward is visible, yet it is almost imperceptible and is due to an improvement - estimated at 2% - in the economic field, which takes into account participation, pay and advancement in the workforce. Even if, statisticians warn, the situation could quickly worsen if we do not invest in artificial intelligence training, where the gap is three times greater than in other fields. According to data collected on the online CV platform LinkedIn, only 28 percent of professionals in the sector are women.Since 2006, the year of the first edition of the WEF index, the path towards equality has remained constant, but slow. Since last year, the situation has improved by just 0.1%. At this pace, equal access to Education, Health and Politics will take a hundred years for women. For the Economy, twice as much. Out of 144 countries, only 17 have a female head of state, the average number of ministers is 18 percent, and the average number of members of parliament is 24 percent. There are still 44 countries where 20% of girls are illiterate. “Eliminating the prejudices that prevent overcoming the inequalities between men and women is a pressing imperative both from the economic and moral point of view”, Klaus Schwab, founder of the WEF, denounces. It is not only women who are losing, but the whole world that is losing by persisting in depriving itself of an enormous and unmatchable resource.

title: Flu vaccine shortage spreads throughout Italy
content: Flu vaccine shortage is spreading throughout Italy, early reports say. Official data arrives in March 2019, but it’s clear that demand for the vaccine has been on the rise. Demand has come from those were offered the vaccine for free, as well as healthy adults seeking prevention from the flu explains Claudio Cricelli, president of SIMG (Società Italiana di Medicina Generale e delle Cure Primarie or the Italian Society of Medicine and Primary Care). “It is not so much of a problem that the doses are scarce now, as [supplies] were already dwindling in some areas of the country by mid-November–at the height of the vaccination campaign, which has now ended.” How much this shortage will impact the health of Italians will manifest at the beginning of 2019, when flu epidemic peaks.Inhabitants of Sardinia, Campania, and Emilia Romagna have made it been known that they weren’t able to access the preventive treatment because of flu vaccine shortages in their regions. The situation only slightly improves in the regions of Piedmont, Liguria, Trentino Alto Adige, and Lombardy–although it’s not like people can run to the nearest province for aid, especially now that temperatures have started to drop–making it likely that the central and southern regions of Italy will face the brunt of the shortage impact. The influenza vaccination has been the recommended preventative measure for some time now, especially among certain sections of the population. In the past years, however, it has been very difficult to get this message to the target audience as the consequences of the disease have long been “snubbed”. During the influenza vaccination campaign of 2014–2015, the reporting of 3 deaths within 48 hours of vaccination with Fluad led to the withdrawal of two batches of vaccines by the Italian Medicines Agency (AIFA), before investigations “cleared” the vaccines. The incident fueled skepticism against vaccinations and drastically lowered the coverage rate compared to previous years. However, last year’s virus–which infected some eight million people–helped reverse public opinion on the matter and many more people are willing to seek preventative treatment. And so this year’s spike in demand (to protect the elderly (the most exposed to the complications of influenza) and children (numerically, the most affected by the virus)) has unfortunately not been met by an increase in supply.If the flu vaccine is almost impossible to find today, it is because the production was calibrated for requests registered in 2017, impacting production cycles of heavyweight producers like Sanofi-Pasteur, GlaxoSmithKline, and Seqirus. But in reality it was the regions–who in most cases plan to purchase the doses every two years, which is why they struggle to adapt to unexpected changes in demand–that underestimated the demand from the Italian population. The multinationals only acted accordingly. They provided adequate supply to the requests, only to be pressed to provide more. Producing additional supply is always challenging because, for one, it takes at least three weeks to produce new doses of vaccines, and it is not easy to favor “compensation” from other countries, where the vaccines are accompanied by instructions in another language. In any case, early information from pediatricians, gynecologists, and prevention departments of local health authorities suggests that the majority of the population to be protected today has been vaccinated.Which brings us to another problem: the inability to cope with a widespread increase in demand following a comprehensive flu prevention campaign. “The risk of not making a good impression exists,” one of Italy’s leading public health experts said. “If we want to encourage flu prevention, we must be ready to face an increase in demand”. An earmark to keep in mind for next year.

title: Italy reaches “technical deal” with EU on Budget
content: A “technical” agreement has been reached between Rome and Brussels on Tuesday over Italy’s budget for 2019, forestalling the opening of an infringement procedure against Italy for excessive debt (second-highest in Europe after Greece). About a month ago, on November 21, the Commission had rejected the government’s initial draft budget plan, which saw Italy running a deficit of 2.4% of GDP next year to back up key electoral promises over the pension reform and basic income for job seekers and to jumpstart economic growth, saying such plan breached EU rules  leading to legal action. The new – revised and approved - budget plan sees the deficit down from the initial 2.4% to 2.04%.After sending a letter to the European Commission explaining the new Italian proposal on the budget law, Premier Giuseppe Conte, said the government “has been working to bring the positions closer together without ever betraying the objectives that the Italians have given us with the vote on March 4 – then, during a speech in the Senate, which the opposition highly contested, he added – «We never made any compromises on the key measures in the government’s budget plan».Reiterating that running on a 2.04% deficit will not affect the plan to bring home the ’citizenship wage’ basic income for job seekers and the pension reform, Premier Conte announced that both key measures «will start as planned», for, «the economic-financial estimates about the measures that attracted the most attention (read contested) of our European partners revealed that the resources (needed) were less than forecast». «This allowed to reduce the deficit from 2.4% to around 2.04% without changing the contents, nor the people eligible, nor the time frame of the two measures». Moreover, due to a slowdown in international trade performance, the government has revised its GDP growth forecast for 2019 from 1.5% down to 1%.«The solution on the table is not ideal, it does not provide a long-term solution to Italy’s economic problems, but it does allow us to avoid opening a debt procedure for now, provided that the negotiated measures are fully implemented», said European Commission Vice President Valdis Dombrovskis on the agreement, adding that «the additional measures found by Italy amount to 10.25 billion». Yet the “real math” will be done after Christmas break, in January, once the Budget Plan is definitively approved. Premier Conte and his deputies Salvini (League) and Di Maio (5SM) might be able to breathe a sign of relief, but Brussels is still – and will keep - breathing down Italy’s populist government’s neck.

title: Choc in Spagna: uxoricida liberato uccide la sua avvocatessa e si suicida. I due avevano una relazione
content: Era stato condannato per l’omicidio della moglie. Uscito dal carcere grazie alla libertà condizionata, ha ucciso l’avvocatessa che lo aveva difeso e con la quale nel frattempo aveva allacciato una relazione e poi si è tolto la vita.La vicenda che ha scioccato la Spagna, alimentando il dibattito sulle leggi contro la violenza sulle donne, è avvenuta nella cittadina di Teruel, nella comunità autonoma di Aragona.Il caso riguarda Jose Javier Salvador Calvo. L’uomo, 50 anni, era stato condannato a 18 anni di reclusione per aver ucciso a colpi d’arma da fuoco la moglie, Patricia Maurel Conte, 29 anni, nel maggio 2003. Rilasciato nel 2017 grazie alla libertà condizionata, l’uomo ha iniziato una relazione con Rebeca Santamalia Cancer, 47 anni, l’avvocatessa che lo aveva difeso al processo, secondo quanto riferiscono i media spagnoli.Venerdì, la polizia ha trovato il cadavere della donna, uccisa a coltellate, in un’abitazione a Saragozza, dopo che il marito ne aveva denunciato la scomparsa. Poche ore dopo, Calvo si è lanciato da un ponte a Tuerel.Il caso ha scioccato la Spagna. Su Twitter, il premier Pedro Sanchez ha ricordato che 4 donne sono state assassinate in pochi giorni nel Paese e si è impegnato a continuare a combattere la violenza sulle donne. Il tweet è stato visto come una reazione alla presa di posizione di Vox, il partito di estrema destra e molto influente in Andalusia, che vuole fermare gli aiuti legali per le donne picchiate dagli uomini, dicendo che favoriscono ingiustamente la donna.

title: Scomparsi in Burkina Faso, procura di Roma: “Sequestro di persona a scopo di terrorismo”
content: La Procura di Roma indaga per terrorismo, il governo italiano e quello canadese lavorano con discrezione, dietro le quinte ma senza sosta, per ritrovare in Burkina Faso Edith Biaf e il suo compagno italiano, Luca Tacchetto, dei quali non si hanno più notizie da metà dicembre. L’Unità di crisi della Farnesina segue «con la massima attenzione» il caso e, ha aggiunto il governo canadese, «tutte le opzioni sono sul tavolo». La Farnesina ha chiesto «massimo riserbo». già aperto sulla vicenda. Il governo canadese comunque è convinto che la sua cittadina sia ancora «viva»: si è esposto lo stesso lo stesso premier, Justin Trudeau, sottolineando che garantire la sicurezza dei canadesi, ovunque si trovino nel mondo, continua a essere una delle responsabilità primarie del governo. La polizia federale canadese è sul posto e lavora in coordinamento con gli inquirenti italiani e burkinabè, ha assicurato una fonte anonima del governo di Ottawa.Venerdì due ministri canadesi - il capo della diplomazia, Chrystia Freeland e la responsabile dello Sviluppo Internazionale Marie-Claude Bibeau - hanno incontrato la mamma e la sorella della ragazza, un incontro a porte chiuse che non ha consentito ai media di avvicinarle. «È stato un incontro tra mamme», ha commentato Bibeau: «Abbiamo parlato molto di Edith: sono due donne straordinarie, molto forti».
